TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and senators in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them, for cost saving reasons only, on a special list requiring authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senators in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 139 citizens), Calvert (from 201 citizens) and Panizza (from 407 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,

note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification.

call upon the Senate to request the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X-rated video material (and its R-rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Aulich (from 230 citizens), Devlin (from 239 citizens), Newman (from 199 citizens), Reid (from 77 citizens) and Walters (from 168 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Community Based Child-care Services
PETITION.PARA: The petitioners of the undersigned citizens of Australia being residents of South Australia respectfully showeth: that the humble petitioners respectfully request to maintain and expand public funding for Community Based Child Care Services in Australia, and express total opposition to the withdrawal of the operational subsidy to any user, because it will have a deleterious effect on children's services in South Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray and urge the Instigation of:
1. Urgent discussions with State Governments, bodies representing children's services and the A.C.T.U.
2. That such discussions examine regulations for the quality assurance of children's services.
3. That such discussion be mindful of the need to retain quality children's services and trained personnel to work in children's services.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sporting, Cultural and Community Groups: Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Skateboard Ramp, North Canberra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The people of the North Canberra Community would like to have a Community Skateboard ramp built in the old North Canberra area. There are keen Skateboarders in the area and at present they have to catch 4 buses to use the Woden facility which is expensive, time consuming, and too dangerous a trip for the younger children.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Investments
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President of the Senate and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are gravely concerned at the Government's proposal to reduce significantly the pension and access to fringe benefits of persons who in good faith bought market linked insurance bonds, friendly society bonds, approved deposit funds, deferred annuities, and unit trusts to protect their savings.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, amend the proposed legislation to ensure that it will not apply retrospectively and that provision be made to protect savings against inflation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Romania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia expresses their concern about the situation in Romania, where, after decades of repression and human rights abuses, the bulldozing of 7-8000 villages is imminent.

The wilful destruction of hundreds of thousands of homes, thousands of churches, historic monuments and cemeteries while unprecedented will erase also the cultural heritage of Romania's sizable minorities, among them that of approximately 2.5 million Hungarians from their erstwhile homeland.

Your petitioners humbly request that the Senate shall issue a strong note of protest to the Romanian Government and shall urge the Australian Government to exert utmost pressure on the Romanian Government to abandon the totalitarian plan and to adhere to the international agreements and covenants of which Romania is a fellow signatory.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS BILL 1988INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1988

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering the Industrial Relations Bill as a whole and Australian Democrat amendments Nos 3 and 4 moved together, by leave, by Senator McLean.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening I moved the first two of seven Australian Democrat amendments. I made the point that our amendments have two specific foci, one being the clauses of amalgamation and the formula for amalgamation and the second being processes of collegiate ballots for office-bearers within unions. These two amendments which are now before the Chair seek to revise the formula for amalgamations downwards from a requirement of 3,000 members to 1,000 in the case of employee organisations. I said last evening that the Australian Democrats saw these amendments as constructive and responsible in that we have been approached by a considerable number of small unions who argue that they are unable to find, and will remain unable to find even within the three-year period allowed for adjustment, compatible unions with which to amalgamate successfully. Some indicated that they had in fact pursued the course of amalgamation in recent years only to find that it did not service their needs. They have withdrawn, only to find that this Bill proposes that they be forced into amalgamations which have proven unsuccessful.

SPEECH.PARA: We draw attention to the fact that our revised suggested figure of 1,000 as the minimum required limit for employer and employee organisations is simply in line with the recommendations of the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, which proposed a minimum membership of 1,000 for both employer and employee organisations. This figure will provide an opportunity to meet the needs of smaller unions. This is the figure which the Government in the 1987 Industrial Relations Bill found acceptable and which at that time was acceptable to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU).

We are not convinced that in the interim 15 months there has arisen a need for the Government or the ACTU to argue the non-acceptability of 1,000. The only argument advanced to us by the outgoing Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, was that the credibility of amalgamations required a strong commitment to the formula and that, without this strong commitment, there would be a lack of identification to the process of amalgamations. We do not accept that. I cited last night the fact that the ACTU, in its support of the two documents Future Strategies for the Trade Union Movement and Australia Reconstructed, had endorsed the process of amalgamation. (Quorum formed) I make the point that the amalgamations figure of 3,000 constitutes an increase of 200 per cent on the figure which was acceptable to the Government and to the Australian Council of Trade Unions 15 months ago. This Australian Democrats amendment simply asks the Government to acknowledge that the figure of 1,000 was acceptable to it in its 1987 Bill and acceptable to the ACTU. It was recommended by Hancock, and it is a figure which accommodates the need of the smaller unions and adopts a progressive approach to amalgamation rather than an unseemly accelerated one. I commend the amendment to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In order to expedite the debate, I am happy for the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) to respond at the one time to the comments of both the Australian Democrats and the Opposition on this matter. We have had a lengthy debate on the principles that should underlie trade union amalgamations, trade union structure and so on. It is quite clear that the Opposition's position is that we require a greater degree of flexibility. We are opposed to numerical limits, and our public policy objective is to achieve structures which will encourage single negotiating units within enterprises. In other words, we want to get away from the multiplicity of unions within an enterprise but we do not see size as the determinant of that.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to canvass the arguments that we have already canvassed very extensively in the Committee with respect to the Opposition's own amendments, which are of a different nature to those put forward by the Australian Democrats. However, the Australian Democrats amendment somewhat reduces the restriction being imposed by the Government. Clearly, it is more in line with the principles we are espousing to have a lower limit rather than a higher limit. We would prefer no limit at all, with the associated changes to the objects of the Act and the other provisions that I went into in great detail. The Opposition will support the Democrats amendment to this clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: -The Government does not accept the Australian Democrats amendments. Of 143 federally registered unions, 38 have fewer than 1,000 members and in total they represent about 15,000 members, or less than 0.5 per cent of total Federal union membership. About 68 have fewer than 3,000 members, representing about 70,000 members or less than 2.7 per cent of total Federal union membership. So when we are debating whether big is beautiful or small is beautiful in connection with the size of unions, I think it is important to get in context what we are talking about-a very small proportion of the total Federal union membership. The Government believes that to reduce the minimum number for membership now, two years later than provided for in the earlier Bill, from 3,000 to 1,000 would have less effect in encouraging union restructuring because of the much smaller number of unions which would be affected. For that reason, amongst others, the amendment does not find favour with the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: All of this question of efficiency and community interest turns on the provision in the legislation which gives a union aggrieved by the number, whether it be 1,000 or 3,000, the entitlement to show cause before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. There is ample opportunity provided in the legislation for a union to show that such is the degree of community interest and specialisation, such are the inadequacies of other trade unions to cover the particular calling in question, that the Commission should allow the union to remain with its present small registered membership. We have been through the principles behind these matters before, and I indicate that the Government will not support the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this amendment as being better than the provision in the Industrial Relations Bill. The Bill provides for unions with fewer than 3,000 members to be forced out of existence, in effect. This will affect about 100,000 workers. It means that if the Bill stands as it is, 100,000 workers will be forced out of their unions into other organisations, probably the majority of them against their will. I stand here having been a member of a union for almost longer than I can remember. After a period, if not in the first few years, one develops a loyalty to one's particular organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: I stand here on behalf of those 100,000 trade union members in Australia who will be forced out of their unions into others, to express the feelings they may experience as a result of this legislation. For many of them, particularly those in the skilled area who are in small craft unions, it will be a wrench. Some of those unions have a long history. They go back many years. They are acting somewhat as a close knit family to protect their professions and their crafts and to advance their interests. Over the years a number of arguments against small unions have been advanced. My view is that we should leave it to the workers to decide whether they want to form a particular union. If they do, they should go through the hoops with the Industrial Registrar to see whether their union's constitution is in accordance with the legislation. If it is not, the union will be refused registration. I have heard all the arguments, mainly on demarcation issues, over many years. I wish Senator Chaney was Minister for Industrial Relations--

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept that for a moment and I will not support it.

—Just wait for it. I wish Senator Chaney had been Minister for Industrial Relations 10 years ago. (Quorum formed) I was saying that under the provisions of the Bill about 100,000 workers will be forced out of their unions into other unions. Many of them may be forced out against their wishes. Before the quorum was called I was about to say that I wish Senator Chaney had been the Minister for Industrial Relations 10 or 15 years ago because some Liberal-National Party coalition Ministers for industrial relations blamed the existence of small unions for a problem in demarcation disputes. Everybody in this chamber will remember people saying, `There should be fewer unions because of all the demarcation disputes'. Senator Chaney came into the area two years ago and looked at the facts. Last night he put the facts on the table as was done by me in this chamber some time ago during the term of Liberal-National Party coalition Government. The facts are that small unions do not contribute significantly to demarcation problems. The facts, as he stated them, are correct. Demarcation disputes occur within and between the larger unions. I do not think that Senator Chaney mentioned disputes within unions. Let me remind the chamber that one of the biggest, one of the longest and one of the most costly demarcation disputes in this country was an intra-union dispute between a boilermaker and a fitter in a newly amalgamated union. That is a matter of record. It is a matter of history.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the amendments moved by Senator McLean in that they are at least a better option than that contained in the Bill. I will come back to the point that I frequently made: it is not a question of union structure that will determine industrial relations outcomes. The issue is whether the parties to the system desire to see that system work and desire to see it work with cooperation with other workers in other unions throughout Australia. One of the big problems, I fear, that may arise out of the current push for amalgamation is that we will have a few very large conglomerate unions which will be so powerful, so self-sufficient, that they will not need to take notice of the peak councils, the Australian Council of Trade Unions or the State trades and labour councils. Situations may arise as they have arisen in other countries, notably in America. One or two very large unions called the tune without regard to what their workers wanted. That occurred two decades ago. I do not think that that would be a good thing for Australia. But maybe the horse has bolted. The atmosphere has developed over 20 years-particularly over the last five years-that there is a need for amalgamation for amalgamation's sake. That is reflected to some extent in the legislation but to a very large extent in what is going on outside in the various councils of employer and employee organisations.

These amendments deal with preference to unionists, the right not to join a trade union and conscientious objection. The first amendment, amendment 14, prevents the Commission from granting preference to members of organisations. Since 1904 the Conciliation and Arbitration Act has empowered the arbitral tribunal to include in awards clauses giving preference to unionists. The specific objective of that is to increase the strength of unions in their dealings with employers, particularly in conflicts with employers. Preference in practice, however, usually amounts to compulsory unionism, although technically the High Court of Australia has not permitted the Commission to award compulsory unionism as such. It is this fact which leads the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and others to say that there is no such thing as compulsory unionism in this country. In fact, as is well known to anybody who is in industrial relations or engaged in industry in this country, there are many circumstances where to get a job one is required to have a union ticket. To suggest, therefore, that there is not compulsory unionism is sophistry. There is certainly de facto compulsory unionism.

Preference clauses can require employers to give preference to union members when it comes to engagement, promotion, training or retention of employees. Again, it is not simply an Opposition position that we believe that this should be abolished. The Confederation of Australian Industry made a series of comments on this legislation. It said on 26 August 1988 that it `strongly supports Opposition amendments which will remove the Commission's power to award preference in employment to union members'.

Amendments 33 and 36 to 39 deal with the right to join or not to join an organisation. The amendments delete the conscientious objector clauses and establish the right to join or not to join an organisation. They provide the same degree of protection to all employees who choose not to belong to an organisation as is currently enjoyed by the holder of a certificate of conscientious objection. In other words we will have an established framework within the Act which provides for protection for that very small number of individuals who are able to be classified as conscientious objectors. The approach adopted by the Opposition is simply to extend the same rights, the same legislative protection, to those who are not necessarily, in a technical sense, conscientious objectors but who simply wish to exercise their freedom not to join a union.

The effect of the amendments is to prohibit an employer from dismissing or discriminating in any way against an employee because that employee is not a member of a union. Normally an employer would refuse to employ a person because that person was not a member of a union. Unions are prohibited from putting pressure on employers to discriminate against non-unionists by industrial action or otherwise. An offence against those provisions will be punishable by a fine not exceeding $1,000 for the first day on which the action constituting the offence takes place, plus $500 for each subsequent day on which the action continues.

The Opposition's view is that there are two facets to our opposition to the notion of compulsory unionism in Australia. The first facet is not an economic one: it is a matter of civil liberties, the basic rights and liberties of Australians. We believe that those rights are infringed when people are conscripted into trade unions. It is interesting that that is a view which has the broad support of the Australian people. The Opposition is not asserting some minority view in putting this forward. The Business Council of Australia commissioned a poll and the finding of that poll in 1987 on the question `Do you think membership of trade unions should be voluntary or compulsory?' was that less than 14 per cent of Australians supported compulsory unionism.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is like all polls. It depends what it means.

—One can argue endlessly about polls. As a great Prime Minister once said, the only poll that counts is the election. I think that it would be consistent with all the surveys done by the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems which showed a concern about trade union power and so on. There has been a consistent series of outcomes in surveys of public opinion showing that people have reservations about abuse of trade union power and things such as compulsory membership of trade unions. Whatever statistical error might be involved in any poll, a less than 14 per cent finding in favour of compulsory trade unionism suggests that the Australian norm is to regard trade unionism as a matter of choice on the part of the individuals concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite important to note that in most countries with which we would wish to compare ourselves it is the norm to give protection against any coercion to join a trade union. The trade unions are always telling us that we should look to the countries of Europe as examples of enlightened trade unionism and industrial relations. The document Australia Reconstructed is based on a visit to Europe by trade unionists and officials. They came back with all sorts of lessons which can be learnt from Europe in this field. I remind the Committee that Austria, France, West Germany, Italy and Spain have constitutional guarantees concerning the right not to join a trade union. In other countries such as Switzerland and Belgium the closed shop is forbidden by law. In Britain industrial action to impose a closed shop is unlawful, as is dismissal for non-membership of a trade union. Many of the States of the United States of America have passed laws outlawing the closed shop. In Norway and Sweden-they are countries which seem to be very much admired by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU)-we find that the closed shop, while not technically illegal, is very rare, and that is because the peak employer bodies of both countries forbid their members to enter into such arrangements.

These matters are of significance. It is only because the Government is very much beholden to the ACTU that it is embracing an approach to trade union membership which is offensive to the majority of the Australian people. This issue has been around for a long time. I said that the principle of preferences had been around since 1904. In the debate on this Bill in the House of Representatives in May this year, Peter Shack, a member of the Liberal Party in that chamber, quoted Sir John Quick's comments on the original Conciliation and Arbitration Bill. Let me repeat that quote:

The only justification for the Bill is that, although it interferes with freedom, it does so with the object of securing the greatest good to the greatest number . . . if we want a scheme which will work in a satisfactory manner we must make the necessary provision, even though it may interfere with individual rights and interests.

That is the sort of justification which has been put forward by the people who have supported compulsory unionism or the effective imposition of compulsory unionism. The Opposition rejects that proposition because we believe that it is simply untrue that compulsory trade unionism is necessary for the effective operation of the industrial relations system. I made the point yesterday that we want trade unions to have to earn their membership in the same way as other organisations have to earn their membership-by providing adequate and, indeed, superior services to their members.

On the purely economic front, we express the view that flexibility will greatly advantage Australia and the Australian economy. We believe that it would be of great advantage to the smooth operation of most enterprises if we did not have the closed shop, if we did not have compulsory unionism. Again, we have had an indication in advance from the Australian Democrats that they will not support this amendment. The fact is that the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats in this place are prepared to impose upon members of the Australian work force the requirement that they have to join a trade union, even though it is quite clear that that is not the wish of the work force. As I said before, we hear a lot about rights and freedoms in this place, but it seems to me that this is one of the fundamental rights and freedoms which should be given far greater credence than it is in this country. I commend the amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point I have to make is that these amendments do not sit, in legislative terms, with the rest of the legislation. TALK.START.PARA: —We are not promoting anything except freedom of choice.

—I am saying that it all depends on how it is dressed up. If Senator Crichton-Browne wants to dress it up in that comforting jargon, from his point of view he is entitled to do so, but I challenge that. The Opposition is really proposing a system of weak and fragmented enterprise bargaining units to take the place of existing unions. That is clear not only from these amendments but from a number of amendments which have been moved in the course of this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The essential thrust of the Opposition's amendments is to break down union security arrangements and to encourage those who accept the benefits won by unions but are not prepared to contribute to the process or cost of obtaining those benefits. It would further this by its policy-not reflected in these amendments-of voluntary agreements under which weak groups of workers, or, indeed, weak groups of employers, would be open to exploitation. The so-called voluntary unionism provisions are really a recycling of a go at this area that the Liberal Party had in government in 1982-the so-called Viner Bill. In looking at that Bill, the majority of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations said:

I do not rely on those words. Senator Chaney is quite entitled to say, `We want to unsettle the industrial relations climate; it is too settled altogether'. The point is that these types of provisions have been considered by this chamber before and have been looked at and rejected by a Senate committee. In contrast to the position of the Opposition, I can only say that the Government encourages representative organisations of employers and employees, as does the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. It believes that members of both sets of organisations should take an active part in the affairs and management of those organisations. It does not think that people should be forced to join organisations by illegal or improper means.

A number of clauses deal with these matters: clause 189 deals with genuine association; clause 122 deals with preference to be capable of being awarded by the independent Industrial Relations Commission, subject to very specific criteria; there is protection against employment discrimination; a new clause in the Bill provides new protections for employers who belong to organisations of employers against industrial action based on membership; there is an improved conscientious objection process; a more effective provision prohibiting discrimination against independent contractors; and greater protection for unionists who fail to join in industrial action by prohibiting employment discrimination by their union. In the Government's view these steps represent a moderate and sensible move forward in the current evolution of the industrial relations system in this country.

Throughout this debate we have been arguing about the same essential philosophical differences, and the same philosophical differences arise here. It is because of that and because of the specific nature of the amendments in the context of the conciliation and arbitration legislation that the Government will not accept them. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the amendments that have been moved by Senator Chaney in relation to preference to unionists and the right not to join a union because of the importance of freedom of association. Freedom of association has both a positive and a negative aspect. On the one hand it involves the right to belong to an organisation, in particular a trade union; on the other it involves the right not to belong. This latter right which we believe is so important has never been recognised by the old Conciliation and Arbitration Act and nor is it recognised in this legislation. It is for this reason that the Opposition has moved this series of amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The right to join or not to join a union should be a basic right under democratic principles. Indeed, that right is recognised as such by the great majority of Western countries where it is recognised in law. In the great majority of Western countries there is legal protection for the right not to belong to a trade union. Yet at the same time many of these countries are widely recognised as having industrial relations systems that have produced better results for their people than ours has for Australia. For example, Austria, France, West Germany, Italy and Spain all have constitutional guarantees concerning the right not to join a trade union. In other countries, such as Switzerland and Belgium, the closed shop as we know it is forbidden by law. In Britain, industrial action to impose a closed shop is unlawful, as is dismissal for non-membership of a trade union. Many of the states of the United States of America have passed laws outlawing the closed shop.

If those examples are not sufficient to reinforce the validity of these amendments which Senator Chaney has moved and to persuade the Government to accept them, even in Norway and Sweden-countries lauded by the Australian Council of Trade Unions in its Australia Reconstructed manifesto-the closed shop, although not technically illegal, is a very rare situation. This is because the peak employer bodies of both countries forbid their members to enter into such closed shop arrangements.

The general view that freedom of association also implies the freedom to dissociate was well put by Irish Appeal Judge Kingsmill Moore in his 1961 verdict on the case Education Co. of Ireland Ltd v. Fitzpatrick, He stated:

I think a guarantee of a right to form associations and unions is only intelligible where there is an implicit right to abstain from joining such associations or unions, or, to put it another way, to associate and unite with those who do not join such unions.

Thus protection of the right not to join a union is the norm throughout the civilised world, and Australia's acceptance of the closed shop places it firmly amongst a small minority. Furthermore, it is also clear that the absence of compulsory unionism is compatible with high degrees of unionisation. It is, therefore, not a question of being anti-union on the part of the Opposition. We in the coalition support the individual's right to belong to a union as strongly as we support this very important right not to belong, but we believe that the law should protect both rights equally. The law in Australia does not protect those rights equally because although there is no legislation enforcing compulsory union membership, preference clauses, as are provided in the existing Act and as are retained in this new legislation, assist union pressure to make closed shops and compulsory unionism a practical reality in many industries in this country.

Preference clauses may compel employers to favour union members in such things as engagement, promotion, retention, training and the taking of leave. They place non-union members at such a great disadvantage that the practical effect of those clauses is to make trade union membership virtually mandatory. Of course, this is reinforced in clause 122 of this legislation. Subclause (1) states:

The Commission may, by an award, or by an order made on the application or an organisation or person bound by award, direct that preference shall be given, in relation to particular matters, in such manner and subject to such conditions as are specified in the award or order, to particular organisations . . .
Our amendment will have the effect of changing clause 122 to read:
The Commission shall not, in any award or order, direct that preference be given, in relation to matters relating to employment, to particular organisations or members of organisations.

This will prevent the Commission from granting preference to members of organisations. As is obvious from what I have said earlier, since 1904 the old Conciliation and Arbitration Act has empowered the arbitral tribunal to include in awards clauses giving preference to unionists. This has continued in this Industrial Relations Bill through clause 122. The Confederation of Australian Industry in August this year in a press statement indicated that it strongly supported the Opposition amendments which will remove the power of the Industrial Relations Commission to award preference in employment to union members.

The other amendments which Senator Chaney has moved-namely amendments (33) and (36) to (39)-deal also with the right to join or not to join an organisation. These are amendments to clauses 266 and 319 of the Bill and they delete the conscientious objector clauses and establish the right to join or not to join an organisation. In other words, it will no longer be necessary for someone to establish the requirement of conscientious objection as a means of avoiding membership of a trade union. It will be open to all employees to have that right and to be able to exercise that right.

Our amendments provide the same degree of protection to all employees who choose not to belong to an organisation as is currently enjoyed by someone who is able to obtain a certificate of conscientious objection. Our amendments will prohibit an employer from dismissing or discriminating in any way against an employee because that employee is not a member of a union; nor may an employer refuse to employ a person because that person is not a member of a union. Under this amendment, unions will be prohibited from putting pressure on employers to discriminate against non-unionists by industrial action or otherwise. An offence under the provisions which our amendment will introduce will be punishable by a fine not exceeding $1,000 for the first day on which the action constituting the offence takes place, plus $500 for each subsequent day on which the action continues. We believe that it is important that employees have that right in law not to join a union and that that is clearly established.

The Government has stated on many occasions that there is no such thing as compulsory unionism in this country. I believe that the remarks of Senator Chaney earlier and the points which I have so far made show that that claim is a total fallacy. One needs only to look at the building industry, where frequently we see signs up stating, `No ticket, no work', which confirms the generally held view in the community that we have de facto compulsory unionism in this country. So it is important that we enshrine within this legislation the capacity for the right not to join a union to be absolutely protected.

While a closed shop cannot be formally ordered by the Commission under existing legislation, it would be totally legal under the new legislation. So it means that there are circumstances where trade union membership will be a condition of employment. While such arrangements operate with the acquiescence of employers, this acquiescence is usually obtained because they are threatened with industrial action if they do not cooperate in preserving a closed shop. Very few employers choose, without the threat of industrial pressure, to make trade union membership a condition of employment.

The Opposition very clearly believes that the decision on whether to join or not join a trade union should be one for individual employees alone to make. We totally reject the paternalistic attitude implicit in the current provisions dealing with the right not to join a trade union. There should be no need to show conscientious objection to trade union membership. The extreme difficulty of obtaining a certificate of conscientious objection is revealed by the very low number of certificates granted each year, despite a strong objection from a large number of employees to compulsory unionism. Applicants are put through an extremely difficult test, putting the onus on them to show possession of a deeply held belief against being a member of any association of employees. Mere membership of a union in the past is usually enough to dismiss an application out of hand. Moreover, it is not enough to show conscientious objection to joining a particular trade union even if that union has policies which are deeply abhorrent to the individual. The objection must be to joining any union.

Compulsory unionism clearly interferes with the freedom of the individual. The only defence for compulsory unionism is that the rights of the individual should be subjected to the interests of trade unions in the public interest. I refer to the quote which Senator Chaney mentioned in moving this amendment. He quoted what Sir John Quick had to say in the debate on the original Conciliation and Arbitration Bill in 1904. He said that the only justification for that Bill was that, although it interfered with freedom, it did so with the object of securing the greatest good for the greatest number. But he went on to say that it was simply untrue that compulsory unionism was necessary--

TALK.START.PARA: —No-Peter Shack went on to say.

—I am sorry-Peter Shack was the original user of this quotation. In referring to the quote of Sir John Quick, he went on to say that it was untrue that compulsory unionism was necessary for the effective operation of the industrial relations system. Of course, that is the strong position of the coalition in relation to these clauses and that is why we have moved these amendments. That view is obviously shared in the community at large. In a recent survey conducted by the Business Council of Australia, this question was asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Do you think membership of trade unions should be voluntary or compulsory?

In that survey 81.2 per cent of respondents answered that they thought that union membership should be voluntary. Only 13.9 per cent thought that it should be compulsory. Of course, that clearly shows yet another example of the way in which this Government is out of touch with the views of the community. Only 13.9 per cent of the community supports the clauses which the Government seeks to include in this legislation in regard to compulsory unionism.

We, in the Opposition, support the view that unions ought to be voluntary. It is our belief in individual rights which prompts us to move these amendments, which will guarantee those rights in the industrial relations area. It is not acceptable that a government that claims to profess concern about human rights in other countries and that wants selective rights entrenched in the Australian Constitution-as it sought to achieve in the recent referendum-should put through this Parliament legislation that ignores human rights and international conventions, as does this Bill. So I strongly support the amendments which Senator Chaney has moved in relation to freedom of association and the right not to join a trade union and I urge the Senate to support those amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask Senator Button to clarify a matter for me. Clause 122 (2) (b) states:

TALK.START.PARA: —I am really being asked by Senator Crichton-Browne what clause 122 (2) (b) means. TALK.START.PARA: —If preference is to be given for the prevention or settlement of an industrial dispute, that simply means that there is no place in the work force for the minority. Those who wish to disrupt industry because they want preferences can strike on that basis at any given time, and the Commission is simply able to rule that, for the prevention or the settlement of an industrial dispute, there should be a preference clause. It gives simply no right to the minority, because those who wish to impose their will upon others can continue to pursue their industrial disputation as long as they like. Paragraph (c) states, `for the maintenance of industrial peace . . . '. The same thing applies. It simply means that a group or a union can say that whenever there are no preference clauses there will be industrial disputation. The net result is that the commissioner can be blackmailed, because he can solve the dispute very quickly by automatically or immediately granting preference clauses. That allows no rights to those who do not wish to join a union.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney is quite right: the trade union movement ought to be able to attract members on merit. Clearly the fact that the Government has found it necessary to put these provisions in-which in each case are simply saying that the trade union movement insists on compulsory unionism-means that the unions are not prepared to chance their arm in the free market; they are not prepared to say, `We are so good, membership is so naturally compelling, that people will automatically join us'. The Soviet Union and Poland do not have compulsory unionism, but when one asks people in those countries why they have trade unions they say that they offer particular benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —But organisations are not always attractive, you see. Look at the Liberal Party; look at the membership of the Liberal Party. It has voluntary membership.
—But presumably people join the Australian Labor Party, mistaken as they might be, and join the Liberal Party, discerning as they might be, because they perceive for themselves a benefit.
—Discerning that it needs help in your case.

—No, not because it needs help. But that is not a situation that the union movement is prepared to put itself in. It is not prepared to say, `We can stand alone on our performance and the attraction to workers'. On education the unions simply say, `You have no right not to be a member of the union'. That is exactly the situation the Government has been prepared to commit itself to. It is offering peace at any price to those who insist on compulsory unionism. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.PARA: I ask Senator Button a question with respect to clause 266 (3). It is the provision dealing with conscientious objection, which is the second amendment. Would Senator Button explain to the Committee why exemption is provided for a period of but 12 months, subject to renewal by the registrar? I would have thought that, if a conscientious objector can demonstrate that he conscientiously objects to being a member of a union, he is not likely in 12 months to have a revelation and decide that he wants to be a member of a union. Is it not reasonable that once he has demonstrated he is a conscientious objector he be able to remain so? Why does he have to come back every 12 months and say, `I still do not want to be a member of a union'?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not like a life membership.
—Why isn't it?
—Because he might change his job, for example.
—Well, what happens if he gives evidence and says, `I just don't want to be a member of a union forever-any union.'?

—No. He might change his job. He cannot say, `I am a conscientious objector in a particular situation', then get his plastic card and take it around forever. There is also an annual fee; he pays for the privilege.
—Pays for the privilege of not joining a union?
—No, of obtaining a certificate of conscientious objection.
—That is the same thing.
—No, it is not at all.

—I wish briefly to respond to the Minister's reply, because it seems to me to be inconsistent with the facts. It is not possible to gain a certificate of conscientious objection under the present law on the basis that a person objects to a particular union, to a particular circumstance. As I understand it-and the Minister might advise me if I am wrong-a person's conscientious objection has to be a conscientious objection to union membership per se. So I think the Minister has been quite misleading in his reply. His reply, in so far as he points out that there is a need for an annual fee, is undoubtedly correct, but that could be paid without any sort of sense of additional application or something. That could be an imposed obligation to pay. But I ask the Minister to confirm that what he said is in fact wrong, that one cannot go before the Commission and say, `I am a conscientious objector because I do not like that particular union or these particular circumstances'. That person has to declare a complete objection to membership of a trade union. That is one of the restrictions in the law which we find thoroughly objectionable. We think there are many circumstances in which an individual might feel he would be perfectly happy to join, let us say, the Vehicle Builders Union because he thinks that is a terrific union, doing a terrific job, but he does not want to be a member of some other union because he thinks it is just a bunch of people creating industrial problems in his place of employment. That sort of choice is simply not open to somebody under the law and we believe that is the sort of choice that should be open to Australian workers.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an application made in respect of conscientious objection and it is dealt with, as I understand it, by a hearing, in which circumstances the person concerned has to establish the genuineness of his claim, if you like. That normally goes to the question of evidence surrounding the circumstances of his workplace, as I understand it, and that is what would be done. If I gave the impression before that it had--
—I think you are quite wrong in your description of the situation. That is precisely the point I was challenging. The particular workplace specifically will not get the man exemption.

—No, the objection is general. The honourable senator is right. If I misled him about that in my earlier remarks, I apologise. The objection is general. But in establishing the general objection the person has to establish the genuineness of his objection. Although it is not in the legislation, I understand that he does that by establishing the nature of his objection and illustrating it in particular circumstances. That, as I understand it, is the way it happens-I may be wrong. I touched on the question of the payment of an annual fee. That is the reason for renewal. I will certainly ask the Minister to have a look at this question to see whether there can be some improvement in those procedures. On first sight they seem a little clumsy to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond very briefly to a couple of points that have been made by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). I would like again to deal with the point that he has just made. The clause that we have sought to delete and replace is quite clear. A person has to satisfy the registrar that his conscientious beliefs do not allow him to be a member of an association of the kind that is dealt with in this legislation. In other words, it has to be a quite general belief. Suppose someone says, `I have a conscientious objection to being a member of a union'. The union will say, `Are you a member of the NRMA?'. If he says yes, the union will say, `There you are; you haven't got a conscientious objection to this sort of thing'.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very narrow group of people who are entitled to claim exemption under these provisions and have protection given to their individual freedom. I would suggest to the Minister that his explanation might be a more acceptable approach. The Minister, in his earlier comments, at least suggested that if the circumstances of a particular workplace led a person to object that would be considered. The law would be a little fairer if that were true. I would ask the Minister to consider changes that would make the law as he described it rather than the law that he is seeking to have enacted here today.

To go back to the Minister's original comments, may I say that there is no intention and no wish on the part of the Opposition to unsettle the industrial relations climate. We want a more flexible system, which is what the Government itself-through the mouth of the various Ministers, including the Treasurer, Mr Keating-has said it wants. The Confederation of Australian Industry, which has been consulted on this Bill as part of the National Labour Consultative Council, supports the approach we are suggesting with respect to preference to unionism. This is not some sabotage of the legislation and it is not something outside the scheme of the legislation.

In the countries that I gave as examples, including Australia, where there is a constitutional guarantee against the requirement that one join a union, there are very high levels of union membership. In other words, having voluntary membership guaranteed is quite compatible with a high level of union membership. It depends how satisfactory the trade unions are to the people whose membership they require. We have no objection to trade unions attracting membership. They do so by the quality of the service that they provide for the membership.

In our view it is in the economic interest of Australia, but even more importantly it is an acknowledgment of basic rights of Australians, that people be able to choose whether or not they join a trade union. I believe that our amendments should be carried. They certainly would be carried if the people of Australia had a direct vote. This is one of those occasions when I wish these matters were determined by referendum rather than by legislative action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no wish to hold this legislation up. May I make two points to Senator Button. Firstly, in my view, to say that we believe in the promotion of freedom of choice is not, as Senator Button said, comforting jargon.
—I didn't say that.

—Yes, the Minister did. I said that we were promoting freedom of choice and he said, `You might use that comforting jargon'. He went on to say that we were promoting weak and fragmented unions. Senator Chaney has covered that. Of course we are not. The unions will be more dynamic. Outside of politics we have always argued for strong, responsible unions. Nobody benefits from weak and fragmented unions, as the Minister describes them. If unionism is voluntary, trade unions will be strong, virile, effective and functioning trade unions which will achieve for their members that which is not presently achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the European Trade Union Confederation in the United Kingdom has had so much success because it has offered trainee programs and a whole scope of benefits to its members, which has caused it to be one of the few unions in the United Kingdom whose membership is going up. That is the sort of union the Minister should be aiming for in Australia, not the dead hand of compulsion that allows a few trade union leaders to manipulate not only individuals but the economy of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer very briefly to the comments that have been made here. I think the best way of doing this would be to refer honourable senators to the final report of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation of October 1982. That Committee was established when the Viner legislation came before the Parliament. It received evidence from various groups and individuals, sorted through a substantial amount of evidence, heard witnesses and made a report to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the matters which the Senate charged the Committee to address was this issue of preference for unionists-whether the provisions of the old Conciliation and Arbitration Act in relation to preference should be maintained or whether they should not. It should be recalled that the Viner amendments in regard to the question of preference for unionists were not particularly different from those being proposed in amendments proposed by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) in this chamber. One of the problems is that it has been construed that having provision for the Commission to award preference for unionists means compulsory unionism, a closed shop. It does not. I am opposed to compulsory unionism and I am opposed to the closed shop. I am very much in favour of a conscientious objection clause that is quite broad.

I wish to quote to the chamber the observations of that Committee because I was Chairman of that Committee and the Leader of the Government (Senator Button) was a member. You, Mr Chairman, were a member also but I think you dissented on this particular aspect. For the benefit of the Committee I will read what the Senate Select Committee said in respect of this issue:
The Committee notes that the Government intends that its proposed legislation will weaken the power of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to deal with union membership disputes.
That is in respect of preference for unionists. It continued:
The Committee shares the view generally expressed by witnesses that the proposed legislation-
I interpolate here `and the amendment of the Leader of the Opposition'-
would not be conducive to industrial peace and would further unsettle the industrial relations climate.
The Committee notes that the Government also intends its legislation to `provide a better balance in the powers, rights and duties of employers and employees'.
Frankly, whilst that is not the stated objective of the amendment, that is precisely the outcome. It continued:
Clearly, this legislation would fundamentally disturb this balance in favour of employers.
Clearly the amendment moved by the Opposition would fundamentally disturb this balance in favour of employers. The report continued:

The Committee considers that the proposed legislation is an undesirable and unwarranted intervention into the field of industrial relations particularly at a time when high levels of unemployment have already disturbed this balance.

That is my concern at the present moment. I am concerned that if there are not strong, representative unions and if they are not able to achieve awards which will protect the weak we will have a situation where, because of high unemployment, people will be offering themselves for jobs in industry at lower rates of pay. I think that that also may be the outcome of some of the other amendments before this chamber last night and today. The report continued:
The Committee believes that viable unions are essential for the operation of Australia's system of conciliation and arbitration.
The Committee considers that the proposed section-
relating to the abolition of preference-
would undermine this viability to an unacceptable extent and it recommends that it not be incorporated in the Act.
The report continued:
The Committee notes further that the Government intends that its legislation ensure `the protection of the rights of the individual'.
The report then made an observation that is apt to the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition today:

Some individuals are quick to recognise their perceived rights but are not also as quick to recognise their duty to associate with others for the common good. In addition there is a distinction between personal choice based on conscientious belief on the one hand and the dictates of self-centred individualism on the other.

I think that is something that this Committee should consider. What the amendment of the Leader of the Opposition proposes to do is to delete the provisions relating to conscientious objection. So really it will not be a test of whether a person's individual conscientious rights are preserved but whether a person's self-centred individualism is preserved. Why should people be able to gain the benefits which are paid for by fellow workers, having refused in a self-centred, individualistic way to contribute? Frankly, I would prefer to provide as broad a provision as possible relating to conscientious objection which would thoroughly protect the conscientious objections of certain individuals to belonging to trade unions, than to leave it up to the self-centred desires of a particular individual not to contribute as he or she is duty bound to contribute. I do not particularly like some aspects of the provision in the Government's legislation because I think it is a little too narrow. However, I believe that if this Committee supported the Opposition Leader's amendments that would certainly disturb the balance in favour of selfishness and self-centred individualism of particular persons who are not prepared to play their part.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (15) Page 55, subclause 124 (1), line 27, leave out ``Subject to this section, the'', insert ``The''.
(16) Pages 55 and 56, subclauses 124 (2) and (3), line 32 (page 55) to line 4 (page 56), leave out the subclauses.

The amendments relate to clause 124 of the Bill, which concerns strike pay. The Opposition's amendments restore the existing prohibition preventing the new Industrial Relations Commission from dealing with claims for strike pay. The existing Conciliation and Arbitration Act specifically says that the existing Commission has no power to make an award or recommendation for payment in respect of a period when employees are engaged in industrial action. But in clause 124 of this Bill, which refers to the limitation on powers of the Commission relating to payments in relation to periods of industrial action, subclause (1) says:

Subject to this section, the Commission is not empowered to deal with a claim for the making of a payment to employees in relation to a period, whether before or after the making of the claim, or before or after the commencement of this section, during which those employees engaged, or engage, in industrial action.
Subclause (2) says:

Subsection (1) does not prevent the Commission dealing with a claim for the making of a payment to employees in relation to a period before the making of the claim but after the commencement of this section during which those employees were engaged in industrial action where the Commission is satisfied that the industrial action was justified by a concern on the part of the employees:
(a) that was reasonable;
(b) that was about their health or safety; and
(c) that arose in relation to matters within the reasonable responsibility of the employer concerned.
Subclause (3) says:

Where the Commission is satisfied as to the matter mentioned in subsection (2) in relation to some, but not all, of the employees, the Commission is only empowered to deal with so much of the claim as relates to the employees in relation to whom the Commission is satisfied.

This Bill therefore permits the Commission to award strike pay in disputes where it is quite satisfied that the industrial action was justified on health or safety grounds. This clause has been strongly opposed by employers as an open invitation to blatant abuse. A recent report on work practices in the building industry by Professor Vernon Ireland, Dean of the Faculty of Architecture and Building at the University of Technology in Sydney, found a significant correlation between the time lost through industrial disputes and the number of strike days paid for-that is, the more strike days that are paid for the higher the level of disputation. On 26 August the Confederation of Australian Industry indicated in a press release strong support for our amendments to this clause, which would make strike pay illegal. Amendment (15) removes the words `Subject to this section', from subclause 124 (1), so that it will then read:
The Commission is not empowered to deal with a claim for the making of a payment to employees in relation to a period . . .

Then there will be the reference to the period relating to industrial action. That is as the subclause is worded. Amendment (16) has the effect of completely removing from the legislation proposed subsections (2) and (3). Those subclauses provide for the provision of strike pay with regard to matters of health and safety.

This provision in the legislation which allows for strike pay in certain circumstances is, as I said, a significant change from the existing legislation and is certainly a backward step from the existing Act. The guidelines which have been provided relating to health and safety in this clause are open to very wide interpretation and in practice it will be very difficult for the Industrial Relations Commission to restrict the awarding of strike pay for disputes concerned solely or primarily with these criteria. Of course, one might argue that in matters of health and safety industrial action may be justified and therefore in those circumstances strike pay is justified. But it really is opening a pandora's box because of this capacity for wide interpretation and the difficulty of the Commission to limit its decisions to genuine claims relating to health and safety. This is already exemplified in the building industry, where the principle of strike pay on matters of health and safety has already been accepted and the way in which these provisions have been abused by trade unions has become a matter of great concern.

I guess, as I said in the second reading debate, that the concept of strike pay represents perfect Labor logic. After all, if one can pick up a travelling allowance for not travelling, why not pick up a working wage for not working? The coalition believes, and it is clearly stated in our industrial relations policy, that health and safety issues should be resolved by appropriate inspection and mediation, not by unilateral industrial action. There are any number of cases in the building industry of stop work action being taken in the name of health or safety or employer negligence which was in fact little more than an excuse to have a paid day off work. No real health or safety issue was at stake at all. There are many instances of building workers using very minor or irrelevant issues as an excuse to pull everyone off the job. I gave some examples of those in the second reading debate. Weather conditions which affect only two or three workers and the non-union membership of a qualified first aid person on site are hardly issues which qualify as a sufficient threat to health and safety to justify workers walking off a job and going home. Yet there are numerous welldocumented cases where this is just the sort of abuse that goes on in relation to industrial action over health and safety issues. It is a cause of major concern among employer groups and indeed among members of the general community, who are growing sick and tired of being held to ransom by large union groups for no apparent worthwhile or justified reason.

This Bill offers what amounts to a virtual open invitation, through clause 124, for unions to go on strike and it is for that reason that the Opposition is moving amendments (15) and (16), which will ensure that the existing prohibition in the present Conciliation and Arbitration Act on the Commission being able to award strike pay will be retained in this new Bill. The coalition takes the issue of strike pay very seriously. When in government, we will make it an offence for any employer to pay or any employee to accept strike pay and we will amend the Act to prohibit a union from taking industrial action in pursuit of a demand for strike pay. But I hope we do not have to wait until the next Liberal Government is elected, at the next election, to achieve that goal. I hope the Government is sensible enough to accept the amendments I have moved today on behalf of the Opposition to ensure that there is no opportunity under this new legislation for strike pay to be granted. In our view, the granting of power to the Commission to award strike pay is immoral and unacceptable and will only lead to an unprecedented wave of strikes across the nation. If we are to avoid total industrial anarchy we must accept amendments (15) and (16) which I have moved on behalf of the Opposition. I urge the Senate in committee to accept those amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Chapman. I do not wish to add to the debate except to comment that it does have a surface appeal to say that the one form of strike the Government will allow to be paid for is one which has to do with health and safety. Senator Chapman made the point that there is widespread abuse of health and safety issues. When the Industrial Relations Bill was introduced, the Employers Federation of New South Wales put out a press release which detailed some of the sorts of abuses which occur in the building industry where absolutely farcical issues have been used as a basis for health or safety issues. Again, rather that prolong the debate, I simply seek leave to incorporate that press release in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
NEWS RELEASE FROM THE EMPLOYERS' FEDERATION OF NSW
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
STRIKE PAY CLAUSE MUST
GO-EMPLOYERS

A clause in the Federal Government's new Industrial Relations Bill which allows the Arbitration Commission to award strike pay to workers involved in some industrial disputes is an open invitation to blatant abuse, a leading employer spokesman said today.

The executive director of the Employers' Federation of NSW, Garry Brack, said: ``What the Government is proposing is to encourage by legislation all sorts of rorts which are being perpetrated already by some unions in the name of health and safety.''

The Bill, introduced in Parliament three weeks ago by Industrial Relations Minister Ralph Willis, proposes to allow the Commission to award strike pay in disputes where it is ``satisfied that the industrial action was justified by a concern on the part of the employees (a) that was reasonable; (b) that was about their health and safety; and (c) that arose in relation to matters within the reasonable responsibility of the employer concerned.''

This is in sharp contrast with the existing Conciliation and Arbitration Act, which specifically says the Commission has no power to make an award or recommendation for payment in respect of a period when employees are engaged in industrial action.
``What the Government is proposing will give carte blanche to the unions to use any pretext, no matter how minor, to go on strike and say there's a health or safety issue involved,'' Mr Brack said.
``There's enough of this kind of thing going on already, without giving it the stamp of authority of an Act of Parliament,'' he said.
``In the building industry, in particular, all sorts of so-called safety issues, which are nothing of the kind, are being used as excuses for walking off the job.
``There have been instances where workers won't walk across an even slightly wet floor on a construction site.
``In some cases they won't even use alternative access routes to walk around a puddle on the floor.
``In other cases they've refused to walk short distances from site sheds to building work which is under cover.

``In yet other cases, if it's wet on the roof where two or three people may be working, everyone on the site could walk off together, even though 95 per cent of them might be working under cover-all in the name of an alleged safety issue.
``In other words: one out, all out; and in such circumstances there is even a refusal to allow the workers from the roof to be redeployed to a dry area.''
Mr Brack said there had been cases where a protective cover had been put up to keep the rain off workers walking to a site, and they had refused to work because the cover had sprung a slight leak.

``In another case involving a wage dispute, this time in the manufacturing sector, storemen and packers claimed that the odd pothole in a road made it unsafe to move materials with forklift trucks, even though they didn't have to go anywhere near that section of roadway.''
Mr Brack said some unions were also using the issue of first aid as a convenient way of creating industrial disruption.

``The BWIU, for instance, insists that the first aid person on the site has to be one of its members-even if there's a triple-certificated nurse or some other qualified person among the employer's people-and then uses the first-aider's absence, for whatever reason, as an excuse to pull everyone off the job.

``The BWIU is supposed to leave the first aid person on the job if its members leave the site during a dispute, but often doesn't, which means members of other union walk off, too, and the site has to shut down completely.
``There have even been instances where unions have walked off a site just because there has been a temporary loss of power to the first aid shed.''
Mr Brack said these examples indicated why employer groups were also expressing concern about another of the new Bill's provisions aimed at reducing the number of trade unions in Australia.

``This proposal to foster bigger unions is already being seen, and used, by some of the larger unions to try to gain control of areas of work where they did not previously have membership coverage,'' he said.
``In the result, these unions will simply become even more powerful and arrogant than they are now.

``We certainly don't need any legislative encouragement for industrial anarchy, and we believe strongly that the Government should abandon this highly dangerous clause and also maintain the current ban on the Commission granting strike pay.''

This amendment is being moved to broaden the range of industry consultative councils to which the terms of clause 133 can apply. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (17) Page 67, clause 146, lines 26 to 31, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Commencement of awards
``146. (1) An award or a variation of an award shall be expressed to come into force on a specified day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of brevity, I rise just to make the point that the Commission cannot award an increase in rates of pay retrospectively in the sense that it cannot award an increase beyond the date on which the first claim on the employer was made.
