TALK.START.PARA: —I now move to Opposition amendment (19), which I propose to deal with separately from amendments (20) and (21). Those three amendments, although grouped together in the list that has been circulated, involve different considerations. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (19) Page 72, Division 8 of Part VI, lines 12 to 37, leave out the Division.

This amendment deals with the subject of overriding State legislation. All members of the Committee would be aware that different States have taken different action to try to ensure that very destructive industrial disputes will be avoided. One of the most contentious and best known examples of that was the attempts made by the Queensland Government-I might say ultimately highly successful attempts-to take action with respect to the South East Queensland Electricity Board industrial dispute in which the trade unions were seeking to limit the capacity of the Electricity Board to use contract labour for maintenance. That dispute happened years ago, but I am sure that it is still fresh in the memory of many people, particularly those people in Brisbane who saw their freezer food destroyed and had all the problems of no refrigeration, no air-conditioning and, in some cases, no capacity to cook. People remember the suffering that was engendered for old and sick people. It was the sort of industrial dispute which causes most Australians to feel very upset and to feel that at times trade unions seriously abuse their power. That sort of strike is at the heart of the statistics which show that the great majority of Australians are very concerned at excesses of trade union power and abuses of trade union power.

Different pieces of legislation have been passed by the States to take these matters in hand. Most recently in New South Wales a serious dispute on the waterfront was dealt with by the State Government, which indicated it would use its essential services legislation and impose very heavy penalties if the strike continued.

TALK.START.PARA: —You need a change of government in Victoria.

—Senator Chapman says that we need a change of government to get that sort of action. I remember that the late unlamented Unsworth Government, in its final days when it was seeking desperately to be re-elected, called upon the emergency legislation with respect to a transport strike.
—Not the Cain Government.

—The Cain Government, I am afraid, is unlikely to show the same nerve, but I do not think it will be around for much longer for us to worry about anyway. However, I should not be distracted. The point is that the constitutional governments of the States have adopted their own provisions seeking to deal with this vexed problem. The inadequacy of many of the remedies was demonstrated earlier this year in Victoria when very significant transport strikes caused tremendous dislocation for people working in the city of Melbourne. It was an example of the ineffectiveness of existing remedies and existing State legislation. I am sure the commuters of Melbourne have not forgotten that dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: In this legislation the Government is seeking to reduce the impact, to minimise the effectiveness, of State laws dealing with industrial action. The amendment which has been moved by the Opposition will simply preserve to the maximum extent possible the capacity of the States to have their own measures to deal with this sort of anticommunity industrial disputation. We have a number of concerns with division 8 of this legislation. Those concerns have been reflected by the State Government spokesmen who have been in touch with us.

To underline the fact that this is not just a concern of the Federal Opposition, I wish to refer to the representations which were made by the Queensland Government and by Minister Vince Lester of that Government. Quite clearly they are concerned that the very effective steps that the Queensland Government has taken to reduce the impact upon consumers of this sort of strike activity may be undermined by what the Commonwealth is proposing in this legislation. Mr Lester says:

The Bill provides that an action under a law of a State or Territory does not lie against a trade union, or an officer, member or employee of a trade union, in relation to boycott conduct. This includes both Federal and state registered unions . . . In addition the Bill provides that State or territory legislation will not apply to conduct that is a breach of an order by the Commission in respect of industrial action by Commonwealth public sector employees or to Federally-registered unions in relation to breaches of bans clauses of a Federal award.
Mr Lester goes on to point out that if the provisions in the Bill are valid they would override the Industrial (Commercial Practices) Act of the State of Queensland.

Again, I wish the Government would put these matters to referendum. I suspect there would be no doubt that within the State of Queensland there would be overwhelming support for the Queensland legislation. I have absolutely no doubt that around Australia there would be overwhelming support for this legislation even though it is Queensland legislation and does not affect the rest of Australia. But the idea that the public should be protected from unnecessary and destructive strike action is, I believe, certainly very strongly supported by the Australian community. This Government, in trying to reduce the capacity of State governments to take effective action on behalf of their citizens, is clearly flying in the face of the requirements of the public.

The truth is that it is this sort of provision which accurately demonstrates the fact that the Government is very much beholden to its principal supporters in the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The Government really is to be condemned because in this sort of provision it is not serving the interests of the people of Australia. It is serving the interests of a narrow section of the people of Australia-that minority of trade unionists who would be prepared to inflict this sort of difficulty and hardship upon the public. So what we are saying is that we do not believe that it should be part of the agenda of this Parliament to be striking down what have proved to be effective State provisions against strike action.

I believe that the events of recent years ought to have demonstrated to the Government that it should leave to the States the handling of these matters which clearly come within State jurisdiction. Even Labor governments have been prepared to take action. The Unsworth Government and its predecessor, the Wran Government, were prepared to enact legislation in this sort of area. As I said before, the Unsworth Government, at least in its dying stages, was prepared to act. We certainly should not be putting logs in the path of those who would act in this way to protect the public interest. Mr Lester went on to say:

Obviously at the behest of its ACTU friends, the Commonwealth is intent upon emasculating this potent weapon against union thuggery. If it succeeds in this, unfortunately the consequences will affect the entire Queensland community.

I would add that it would potentially affect the entire Australian community. All of us-the people of Victoria, New South Wales, South Australia, Tasmania and Western Australia-will lose the potential protection of State government attempts to deal with this sort of minority but intensely damaging trade union behaviour.

I believe that this is an area in which we should have been able to count very clearly on the support of the Australian Democrats. I think if they asked their constituency whether it was appropriate for the Commonwealth law to strike down the attempts of State governments to deal with this sort of action, most of them would answer a resounding no. I very much doubt whether Senator McLean will be able to get up in this place and say that the Democrat constitution, which permits policy formation by ballot of all Democrat members, will have been followed in this case and that Democrat members will have indicated that they support this sort of approach by the present Commonwealth Government. The Liberal and National parties alone will not be able to block this provision. I think it is a matter of great regret that effective State legislation will now come under challenge because of the failure of the Australian Democrats to support this Opposition amendment.

I should indicate that not only politicians have made representations about this provision. Representations have been made by industry associations. I have before me representations from the Housing Industry Association which expresses its very great apprehension about the possible effect of this legislation on provisions relating to independent contractors and so on.

It is important to note that if the Senate passes this legislation it will certainly not be speaking for the people of Australia. I do not think there is any doubt that the people of Australia would give the strongest possible support to State efforts to make the sorts of provisions that the Commonwealth has made in the Trade Practices Act to prevent secondary boycotts and the quite criminal interference with the public interest which occurs in some of these quite unnecessary strike actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has already been indicated that the Government will not support the amendment, largely for reasons of the ground that we have gone over on several occasions during this debate. To the best of my recollection, no such direction has ever been issued. If any such direction is issued it must be tabled in the Parliament. No such direction has been issued: therefore, the question of the Government not allowing the Reserve Bank to do something is irrelevant.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Stone accused me of not responding to the question. I have responded to the question. He asked me whether the Government was leaning on the Reserve Bank or not allowing the Reserve Bank to do something and I said that it was not. I quoted the Governor of the Reserve Bank. The Governor of the Reserve Bank had his character assassinated by the mere meretricious player in the House of Representatives on Wednesday.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care to the interest rate assessment contained in the current Westpac Banking Corporation Economic Review, which states: `Over the next few months the likelihood is that rates could rise even further'. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. What would be the effect on the Commonwealth revenue of a $56 per week tax cut on average weekly earnings? Will the Government implement such a cut? What is the source of the $56 a week tax cut proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Reference is made in the question to average weekly earnings or, a looser term that is used by some people, average earners. I say at the outset that there is no such thing as a precise definition of either of those concepts. Average weekly earnings are assessed as ordinary time earnings, total earnings, on the survey basis or on the national accounts basis, and there are some variations between all of those things. There is also a very substantial difference, although I believe it is not generally recognised by the public-and overlooking the other imperfections-between average weekly earnings, which is the arithmetical mean and the median income; that is, the income half of which are above and half below. The reason that I gave that explanation is that the figure that I will cite as an assumed average earner's figures, or average weekly earnings, is an income of $24,000 a year. If a person in receipt of a taxable income of $24,000 a year were to receive a tax cut of $56 a week, his taxation liability would fall by 52 per cent. In other words, the tax that he paid would be more than halved.

ANSWER.PARA: This year's Budget estimate for total tax to be paid by individuals, net of the Medicare levy, is $43.5 billion, in round figures. If the taxation liability of all persons were to be reduced by 52 per cent-that is, the proposed $56 a week reduction for persons on $24,000 a year-tax revenue from individuals would fall by $23.5 billion. I said yesterday that the figure was about $25 billion; I have since made a more precise calculation. If that 52 per cent reduction in income tax were to be applied across the board, revenue would fall by $23.5 billion. If any Opposition senator wants a basic lesson in numeracy, I will be quite happy to take him through the figures later on. I suspect it would take quite a long time before most of them would understand it, assuming that they were at all capable of understanding it.

I have been asked to explain the origin of the proposal. I had thought that the proposed $56 a week reduction had originated from Mr Peacock, who gave an interview which was published in the Australian Financial Review of 29 August 1988:

In an interview with The Australian Financial Review the Shadow Treasurer, Mr Peacock, was pleased to suggest personal tax cuts-around $56 a week for average earners to make up for the absence of tax scale indexation since 1983. He would not say how large the necessary spending cuts would be or where they would be made.

The spending cuts required to offset a tax cut of that magnitude would be in the order of $23.5 billion. I thought that Mr Peacock was actually responsible for this ridiculous proposition in the first place, but I found yesterday that the Leader of the Opposition, obviously not knowing what he was doing, claimed responsibility for it. He made a statement during the discussion of a matter of public importance yesterday, the alleged transcript of which he circulated. He stated:

Every family in Australia, wherever they live, ought to understand one thing: that unless they get a taxation cut of $56 a week their living standards are still going to be well below what they were in March 1983, because $56 is the unchallenged calculation of the Opposition of the quantum of the fall in family living standards over the last 5 1/2 years. That figure was first used by me in addressing the Victorian State Council of the Liberal Party in June of this year and it has remained unchallenged ever since.

I interpolate that that is simply not true. It was challenged and, indeed, put down by me during the two-week sittings after the Budget, and again a couple of days ago. The Leader of the Opposition continued.
All the resources of the Treasurer, the Finance Department, the Reserve Bank and all the other minions that surround the Treasurer and Finance Minister can't challenge that figure because it is true.

I did not need the resources of the Treasury or of the Department of Finance. I made those calculations myself-$23.5 billion worth. Three weeks ago I also identified the conceptual error that Andrew Peacock had made. The Peacocks and the Howards are saying that, where nominal incomes increase, nominal taxes must stay the same, otherwise tax has gone up. That is the basis of the Opposition's conceptual error.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank heavens you did not get any of the Treasury people to do it.
—I am quite happy to submit my figures for verification by the Treasury and bring in a report. I would be very happy for Senator Chaney to ask me a question about it.
—The whole thing misses the point entirely.

—Senator Messner has interjected. In a series of increasingly confused personal explanations here over the last few days, Senator Messner has been trying to get the Opposition off the hook upon which it impaled itself by saying that there ought to be a $56 a week tax cut for average earners.
—We have never said that.

—Mr Peacock has been reported as saying it in the Australian Financial Review of 29 August, and there is absolutely no evidence that he has claimed that that report was inaccurate. If Mr Peacock wants to run away from that, I trust that he will do so. But Senator Messner's series of increasingly confused personal explanations-he made the mistake of putting that $56 a week figure in the question-has done nothing to wipe out the $23.5 billion credibility gap.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. I know that you have been listening carefully to the answer, as I have. I think that up to this point he has been in order. But the Minister is now going off on some completely fresh frolic that seems to be outside the terms of the question that was asked. I would ask you to call him to order.
—I think the Minister has finished his answer.

—I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce whether he recalls answering Senator Chaney on 30 August 1988 in regard to the Government's Budget Estimates by saying, `This Government's estimates have normally been pretty right'. Does he recall that on 28 September 1988, in answer to Senator Stone, Senator Walsh said of this Government's Budget Estimates, `They are nearly always wrong'. Since the Budget Estimates cannot be `normally pretty right' and `nearly always wrong' at the same time, can the Minister explain which of these two Ministers has stumbled inadvertently into telling the truth?

—Of course, one is speaking about matters of degree. When I said that this Government's Budget estimates were normally pretty right, I was making a comparison with the Budget deficit estimate, which we inherited, made by Senator Stone. Never in the history of this Government has there been a difference in a Budget estimate such as that which occurred in 1982-83 under the leadership of Mr Howard and on the then advice of Senator Stone, who at least had the integrity to draw the community's attention to that vast discrepancy. We have never seen a discrepancy like that in Budget estimates in the history of this Government.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Since Senator Button says that this is simply a matter of degree, can he tell us in terms of proximity to the truth which is, as a matter of degree, nearer the truth-that the Government Budget estimates are normally pretty right or that they are nearly always wrong?

—I really would like to do a job on that for the honourable senator. I will have a look at that question and provide him with a balanced answer because that is what he requires. The burden of Senator Walsh's point, as I understood it, in Question Time the other day was to say that Budget estimates were just that-they were estimates-and that to that extent they were not projections which could be relied on to the nth degree, if that is the appropriate expression. That has always been so.
—A bit rubbery.

—Nobody has ever used the expression `a bit rubbery' to the same extent as it was used against the Fraser Government. That is when it was invented. It was invented by a Minister in the Fraser Government about his own figures. Nobody has done that in this Government.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I hope to refocus the senatorial consciousness on the real world with this question. My question concerns the deliberate slaughter of at least 100,000 dolphins in the eastern tropical Pacific each year as a result of purse seine fishing for yellowfin tuna which swim beneath and behind dolphin herds. I ask the Minister: Has the Government expressed its opposition to the dolphin slaughter to the responsible governments; namely, those of Mexico, the United States, Venezuela, Equador, Vanuatu, Spain, the Cayman Islands, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Panama and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics? If not, why not? Will the Government ban the import of yellowfin tuna caught in the eastern tropical Pacific until the dolphin kill ends and the level of dolphin deaths is greatly reduced to negligible levels? What other actions has the Government taken, or will it take, to help end this deliberate dolphin kill and to ensure that Australia is not involved in it?

—The Australian Government does pursue a policy of protection for all cetaceans, including dolphins, worldwide. We pursue this policy internationally through our anti-whaling efforts in the International Whaling Commission and nationally through State and Commonwealth legislation. We are concerned about the problem of the unnecessary incidental death of dolphins in the eastern tropical Pacific tuna fishery. Because that killing takes place outside Australian waters it is difficult, obviously, to intervene directly. Mr Hayden did express the Government's concern to the Mexican Foreign Minister, Mr Sepulveda, on 27 July when the Mexican Foreign Minister was in Australia, and I have asked that similar representations be made to the other governments mentioned in Senator Sanders's question. We are at present exploring the possibility of working with other like-minded conservation nations-for example, New Zealand-to help end this unnecessary dolphin kill. I will certainly take into account the views of Senator Sanders and others in the community who share the Government's and my concern with this issue.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Is the Government concerned about the effects on the national economy of any return to high spending policies by the States? Is there any evidence of a possible return to a high spending policy in any of the States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is very concerned about the effects on the economy of a return to high spending policies by the States or, indeed, by some future Commonwealth government and is concerned, in particular, about expenditure blow-outs that are not matched by revenue increases. When the two are put together-that is, an expenditure blow-out which is not only not matched by a revenue increase but accompanied by a revenue decline-the Government is doubly concerned about the effects.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been asked: Is there any evidence of a possible return to a high spending policy in any of the States? The answer is yes, there is a danger of that happening if Mr Kennett should become leader of some sort of a ragtag coalition government in Victoria. In the Australian of today an article by Lim Say Boon lists a number of expenditure promises made by Mr Kennett and a number of taxes and charges which he has promised to forgo. Most of these items, incidentally, I enumerated in the Senate, I think two days ago. That shows a total effect on the bottom line of the Victorian State Budget of a deficit of $511m, comprising just over $200m in forgone income through promises to reduce taxes and charges and just over $300m in promises to increase expenditure. I will go through the major items on the expenditure side: the promise of an extra $53m in education spending; an extra $116m in health; $30m in housing; $70m on police, and $35m on transport.

As I suggested earlier, if any government chooses to increase expenditure and is willing to match that increased expenditure by a greater revenue effort with a commensurate increase in revenue, that is fiscally respon- sible. It is not fiscally responsible to promise to increase spending without increasing revenue. That is fiscally irresponsible. To promise to increase expenditure substantially whilst simultaneously promising to reduce revenue is doubly fiscally irresponsible. That is fiscal ratbaggery as advocated by the Federal Opposition ever since it has been the Opposition, and advocated presently in Victoria by Mr Kennett.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Is the Federal Government now supporting the setting up of a National Crime Authority (NCA) office in Adelaide? Is it proposed that an additional member of the Authority be appointed to head the office and that the legislation be amended accordingly? Does the Federal Government support the granting of a specific reference on official corruption in South Australia? What portion of the financial costs of the proposed Adelaide office will be borne by the State Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say by way of preamble that I am very confident that the South Australian Government will take every step as resolutely as possible to root out such corruption as may exist within the law enforcement agencies of South Australia and, indeed, to set up such conditions as would prevent--
—It has done its best to avoid its responsibility in this area.

—Senator Hill is the shadow Minister for Justice. I should have thought he might ask the question rather than Senator Teague but, if Senator Teague is acting as Senator Hill's substitute, Senator Hill should let him ask the question and make the interjections. I was saying that I believe the South Australian Government has the resolution and the will to root out such corruption as may exist within the South Australian police force and to set in place measures to prevent the emergence of such practices, which undermine the confidence of the public and of the community in the very agency which it should have utmost confidence in as to its integrity for the upholding and enforcement of the law which the community formulates through its elected representatives.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to matters which have occurred over the last week or so, the fact is that the South Australian Attorney-General, Mr Chris Sumner, has approached me to see whether the Federal Government would support the setting up of an inquiry or even an office by the National Crime Authority in South Australia. That is a matter which, under the present legislation, the South Australian Government is required to place on the agenda of the intergovernmental committee. That mechanism would have to be put into operation before the National Crime Authority could be asked to come into South Australia in relation to a matter arising under South Australian law. Even at the request, as I say, of the South Australian Government it cannot be done absolutely unilaterally. As I have said, the South Australian Government has been carrying out some preliminary discussions and when a formal request is made that full mechanism will be implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. This matter is on the front page of this morning's newspaper in South Australia and it is the first sign of the South Australian Government doing anything positive about an NCA office. I ask the Minister the same question I asked him originally: What is the Federal Government's position with regard to an NCA office in Adelaide? Given that the South Australian Attorney-General said yesterday that the State Government has `decided to make a financial contribution' to the cost of that office, by paying it to the Federal Government, what proportion will the South Australian Government be making to that office? What is the answer to the other parts of my questions? Will there be an additional member of the Authority? Will there be an amendment to the legislation and so on?
—Order! To the best of my knowledge that is exactly the same question. The Minister can answer it if he wishes.

—It is not a supplementary question at all. I have tried to explain to the honourable senator that there are procedures under the present statute which must be gone through before this matter can be referred to the National Crime Authority if that is the outcome of the present preliminary negotiations. So all the detail of any arrangement would still have to be worked out. As to the Federal Government giving a response off the cuff, that would be most improper. I have had conversations with the Authority this morning and I think that obviously that is the correct procedure to follow.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories been drawn to a report contained in the Australian Financial Review of Wednesday, 28 September, with the headline `US seeks world ban to save ozone layer'? Does the report reveal that the United States Environmental Protection Agency has called for a total ban on the use of chemicals it believes are destroying the earth's ozone layer? Is there, as the article implies, a growing concern amongst world experts that the situation is more serious than has been previously recognised? Will the Federal Government be seeking to strengthen the provisions of the protocol in light of the new scientific evidence and the alleged claims of the United States Environmental Protection Agency that only a total ban would meet the urgency of the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the article that appeared in the Australian Financial Review regarding chemicals which destroy the ozone layer. The article claims that the United States Environmental Protection Agency believes that a 50 per cent reduction in chemical use, required under the Montreal protocol, does not go far enough given a growing consensus that the threat to the ozone layer is more serious than previously recognised. Senator Richardson announced on 12 July that the Government is proceeding with the drafting of legislation to control ozone depleting substances. It is intended that this legislation will be introduced into Parliament this session. The legislation will provide for two areas of control of ozone depleting substances-namely, controls on supply and controls of applications. Initially, the control of supply will be in line with the provisions of the Montreal protocol which was concluded last year. On the matter of controls on applications it is estimated that the use of available alternative substances and technologies can reduce the consumption of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) in Australia to the order of 50 per cent by 1992 and that substantial further reductions will be achieved as new alternatives become available.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of United States involvement, we welcome its activities in this area. The Government is not convinced, however, that an immediate total ban is either necessary or appropriate given the need for CFCs and halons use in some essential applications and given that there is a lack of conclusive scientific information on the extent of that problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security aware that 15 farming families per week are leaving the land in Victoria and that 4,685 farms have been lost during the last six years of the Cain Government? Is he also aware that rural unemployment in Victoria in this same six years has increased by 90 per cent from 25,100 to 47,800? In view of these tragic statistics, why has the Government discriminated against the rural sector in eligibility for social welfare assistance and why has the Government walked away from its responsibility to rural unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that in the 1930s about 28 per cent of the Australian labor force was employed in agriculture. In the early 1950s that figure was 14 per cent and now I think it is just over 6 per cent. I have heard that sort of bleating that has just come from Senator McGauran coming from Country Party politicians for as long as I can remember. The reason that I despise the Country Party to the extent that I do is that it alone made a virtue of ignorance. Not even the Liberal Party of Australia, with the possible exception of the very recent period, ever actually made a virtue of ignorance. Only the Country Party, now the National Party of Australia, has made a virtue of ignorance. For many years as a farmer I was disgusted by the then Country Party. There were some 80,000 dairy farmers in Australia and the obvious truth was, confirmed by the McCarthy report of 1960, that the only way that the majority of those dairy farmers could earn a decent income would be to move off the land.
—Into the motel industry.

—This was in the 1950s and the 1960s, a time of full employment, Senator Button. It would have been in the interests of the great majority of them to move off the land, to get themselves a decent job, and probably get enough for the farm to buy a house in a regional centre or even a city and have a much better life for themselves and their families. What did the Country Party tell them? Did the Country Party tell them that? No. The Country Party said, `All that stands between you and destitution is the butter subsidy and you have to keep voting for us or the butter subsidy might disappear'.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. There are requirements under the Standing Orders for relevance in this particular matter. Senator McGauran has asked specific questions about the current failure of and maladministration by the Cain Government. The Minister is deliberately not addressing his mind to the question of the maladministration and incompetence of the Cain Government. The answer that he is giving at the moment is in no way relevant to the question that was asked.
—Order! The Minister is in order.

—The question referred to the movement of people out of agriculture-five families a week or whatever it was. I am supplying some highly relevant background information. The Country Party said to many of these dairy farmers, most of whom had extremely low incomes, `All that stands between you and destitution is the butter subsidy. All that protects the butter subsidy is the Country Party'. The Country Party was not concerned about the welfare of the people it purported to represent. The Country Party was concerned about maintaining a sufficient number of Country Party voters living in particular areas to provide electoral fodder for Country Party politicians. Of course, the focus on butter was, for industry structural reasons, very unsound as well.

ANSWER.PARA: In the end, the number of dairy farmers halved and halved again and I think it is now down to about 20,000. So inevitably these forces took over. However, the point is that Senator McGauran, in the late 1980s, is still peddling the same rubbish that the previous generation of Country Party politicians peddled in the 1950s and the 1960s-that is, that everything must be done to stop people moving out of agriculture, regardless of what the economic pressures to do so may be. That is not a view that Senator Stone ever supported when he was Secretary to the Treasury and I am sure, privately, he does not support it now. But I suppose that, looking at his position as Leader of the National Party in the Senate, he would not dare say that publicly. The Country Party has not changed its spots since the 1950s and 1960s, as is evidenced by that question.
Sitting suspended from 1 to 2 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to authorise payments in 1988-89 arising out of arrangements agreed to by the Commonwealth and the States at the 12 May 1988 Loan Council meeting for the payment of:
interest free capital grants to the States (including the Northern Territory); and

funds which the States and Northern Territory may nominate as being for the purpose of public housing, which are provided as loans on the same concessional terms and conditions as set out in the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement.

The $621 million payable to the States and the Northern Territory under this Bill in 1988-89 will be distributed in line with the shares applying to the State Government's Loan Council programs and general purpose capital assistance to the Northern Territory in 1987-88.
No provision is made in this Bill for payments for the Australian Capital Territory. However, provisions in Appropriation Bill No. 2 allow for analogous payments to be made to the ACT Trust Fund.

The Commonwealth agreed at the Loan Council meeting that half of the $621 million would be provided as capital grants, with the States being able to nominate the remainder as loans for public housing, which the Commonwealth will provide on concessional terms and conditions. Any part of the loan component which the States choose not to nominate will be provided as loans at market rates of interest.

Concessional loans for public housing under these arrangements have been available to the States since 1982-83. These loans supplement the specific purpose grants for housing made under the Housing Assistance Act 1984, which implements the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement. Accordingly, the Bill provides that as a condition of the making of these loans a State must be able to meet its matching requirements for the purpose of the Housing Assistance Act. Subject to that, the loans are provided on the terms and conditions set out in the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement, and hence will bear interest at the highly favourable rate of 4 1/2 per cent per annum and will be repayable over 53 years.

Although the same level of assistance will be provided to the States and Northern Territory this year as in 1987-88, it is to be provided on a more concessional basis. As I have indicated, one half, rather than the one third which was the case last year, will be provided as grants. The increase in the grant component has brought about a corresponding decrease in the loan component for public housing. The Commonwealth indicated at the Loan Council meeting, however, that in so far as possible the States should apply the additional grants to expenditures on public housing.

The Bill also provides for advance payments to be made in the first six months of 1989-90, up to a limit of half the total amount payable in 1988-89, of amounts expected to become payable under similar legislation in that year.
The Bill forms an important part of the Commonwealth's overall financial assistance to the States and the funds available for expenditure on public housing.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Boswell proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's neglect of the average worker as evidence by the continual decline in living standards over the last five years.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring this matter of public importance before the Senate because I believe that this Government must be reminded of the responsibility that it has to the average working family, and the average working man and women, which it has neglected over the past five years. How many have been left homeless, how many are poor and how many are unemployed? One out of every five of our young people has not got a job. How many people are queueing for hospital beds? How many workers cannot afford to clothe, house, educate and feed their families?

SPEECH.PARA: A cursory glance at any of our economic indicators would show the pattern of neglect that this Australian Labor Party Government has inflicted on Australia since it took office. Far from advancing the welfare of the blue-collar worker, the one income family person-this Government's historic and traditional base-the Australian Labor Party today is pursuing policies that are allowing a system of social and economic apartheid by neglecting the average worker and his family while favouring big business and big unions and pandering to the whims of vocal and radical minority groups in order to stay in office, groups such as the greenies, the feminists and all those types of other odds and sods and remnants. It has neglected the welfare of the worker and family people in Australia.

Let us look at housing. The cost of buying a home has nearly doubled under this Government. The first home owners scheme funding has been cut. The number of people on waiting lists for home purchase assistance stands at 79,000. More than 60,000 people have joined the housing queues since this Government took office. The Government has pursued policies to advance welfare housing rather than allowing the average Australian to own his own home. In 1984 the average monthly home repayment was $335-based on an average home loan of $33,000 at 11.5 per cent over 25 years. In 1988 the average home loan repayment is $620-based on a home loan of $55,000 at 14.5 per cent over 25 years. It has doubled in four years under this Labor Government's mismanagement of housing.

Home ownership is less affordable today than it has been at any other time. I am glad that Senator Walsh, Minister representing the Treasurer, is here. It requires an average annual income of $39,500 to qualify for a home loan. Yet the average worker, not the mean average that Senator Walsh went into so much detail to explain to us today, earns only $34,500 a year-and that is a considerable amount of money. What about the $17,000 people? What about the $23,000 people? They have been completely neglected. The Government has reduced the first home owners scheme so that a family with one child receives only $2,000 in deposit assistance. In 1981-82 Commonwealth funding was split 46 per cent for purchase assistance and 54 per cent for public housing. In 1986-87 it was reduced to 27 per cent for people purchasing their own homes and 73 per cent for welfare housing.

We have longer queues for welfare housing and the dream of all Australians to own their own home is fast fading away. In this country people deserve the right to own their own home. This country has everything to offer and yet we cannot provide a home to people unless they are earning an income of $39,500. They are the only people who are eligible to own their own home or to receive a home loan.

We see that this Government has called for a review of housing initiatives. It has floated proposals such as a wealth tax on homes over $300,000 and a capital gains tax on the family home. There are 40,000 people permanently homeless in Australia today. There are 60,000 people living on the verge of homelessness in caravans and the backs of cars under family homes. Is this what the blue collar worker deserves? Is this what the workers deserves from this Government?

Let us leave housing and go to education. Who would have ever thought a Labor Party government would legislate to introduce charges for education? Where is the egalitarian spirit of the Labor Party in discriminating against children in rural areas by imposing assets tests which restrict their rights to an education?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an utter disgrace.

—It is an utter disgrace. In Question Time today, when Senator McGauran tried to raise a matter of extreme importance to the rural electors of Victoria he was castigated by Senator Walsh in the most insensitive attack I have ever heard in this Parliament. Senator McGauran was trying to bring the plight of the farming community before this Parliament. He was abused and castigated by Senator Walsh. What Senator McGauran was trying to tell the Senate was that 15 farming families per week are leaving the land in Victoria and that 4,680 farmers have left their farms or been forced off their farms in the last five years.

SPEECH.PARA: Taxation as a percentage of gross domestic product has continued to rise despite the promises of the Labor leaders. It is not the Brierleys, the Bonds and the Holmes a Courts of this world who are paying, but the workers and their families. There has been a litany of extra taxes and charges imposed by this Government-taxes and charges which mean that it can be rightfully awarded the title of highest taxing government this country has ever known. The millionaires of this country have got their tax cuts, but what about the workers of Australia? They have to wait until July next year before they get their tax cuts. And this is the government of the worker; the government of the battler! The Government has neglected its base shamelessly.

Let me remind the Senate that in March this Government introduced a pensioner assets test which caused so much hardship to rural Australia. The Government has never cared for farmers. This was the hardest knock that this Labor Party has ever inflicted on the farmers. I see that Senator Panizza agrees with me. In 1985 the Government raised the prescription fee by $1 to $5. What happened then to all the people who needed prescriptions? It meant another $4 every time the average worker went to get some cough medicine or other medicine for his kids. This is the most insensitive government that Australia has ever seen. The Government has removed the Medicare levy limit. It has imposed the fringe benefits tax. It has imposed new and increased sales taxes. Furthermore, the Government increased the excise on petrol and diesel fuel by 3c a litre. It has increased tax on wine to 20 per cent. It has imposed a 10 per cent sales tax on flavoured milk, fruit juice, non-alcoholic wine and cider. But the lowest thing the Government has ever done is tax the kids' ice-cream. That is how low the Government has gone: it has taxed the ice-cream of kids in Australia. I look at Senator Bjelke-Petersen here and know that she is very concerned about this matter. She is a grandmother and she knows what it is to go and buy her five or six grandchildren an ice-cream. She can probably afford it but there are a lot of grandmothers out there who cannot even afford to buy their grandchildren ice-creams because of the absolute meanness of this Labor Party Government.

The Government has abolished the family allowance for dependent students aged 18 to 24 years. It is means testing the allowance for 16- and 17-year-olds. In December 1986 the Government increased the Medicare tax levy from one per cent to 1.25 per cent. In January 1987 the Government imposed tertiary fees of $250 per student. Where were the ethics, the philosophy and the ethos of the Labor Party Government? Income testing on family allowance for joint incomes of $50,000 a year and above has been imposed. The maximum benefit for the first home owners scheme has been cut by $1,000. There have been new superannuation taxation arrangements introduced. Commonwealth funding to non-government schools is to be cut by $12m over the next three years. The patient contribution to pharmaceutical benefits has increased from $10 to $11. I could go on and on but I would need an extension of time to read out this litany of increased taxes. Beer excise has been reduced, but sales tax on beer has been increased; tertiary education fees have been replaced by a new graduate tax; and family allowance funding is to be cut by $39.2m through assets testing. The total tax revenue for 1988-89 will increase by nearly 10 per cent to a record 25.7 per cent of gross domestic product. Despite the increases in taxes and cuts in essential programs, Government spending has increased and it is forecast to rise to a massive $82 billion-an increase in 1988-89 of over 4 per cent.

What do the workers have in common with this group of people that wants to destroy 2,500 jobs in the Queensland rainforest areas? It is absolutely shameful that this Government is destroying those jobs in the tableland area of Queensland. Those 2,500 workers trusted the people opposite; they paid their union fees and sent unionists down here to represent them in the Parliament, only to have their livelihoods removed, to have their jobs and their families destroyed. What sort of workers party has the Australian Labor Party degenerated into? Where are the unionists in here? I will tell you where they are-they are ashamed to come here, they are ashamed to listen to this Government because it has destroyed the workers' livelihoods. It has neglected its base, it has neglected the unionists and now those opposite are running a government for the high and mighty.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the powerful.

—Yes, and the powerful. The Labor Party and the workers have always worked together in the past to fight for greater justice and a higher standard of living. But that is the past. Where are the champions now? Where are the men and women who slogged their way up through the ranks and, through pure grit and determination, came here to represent the working men? Where are the Ben Chifleys, the Mick Youngs, the Eddie Wards, and the Clyde Camerons-the shearers and the train drivers? The most endangered species in the Labor Party is the working man. Who do we have here who represents working men? Senator Devlin is a worker.
—Are there two?

—No, Senator Devlin would be the only one who has ever picked up a tool in anger in his life. Senator Devlin is a worker; he does represent the working man. While Senator Collins and Senator McMullan are waiting to get on the front bench they should form themselves into a task force and actually go out and try to recruit a few working men to represent the people.
—They wouldn't know where to look.

—If they do not know where to look, I will tell them. The workers that Labor represents are being reduced to living in eight-square dogboxes on cement bases. They work 40 hours a week for which they bring in about $250. Out of this they pay $120 rent. They are the people who want representation in this Parliament. They do not want the machine men, the Labor Party bureaucrats-the doctors, the solicitors and the barristers. The Labor Party should have a sprinkling of them, but how about putting in a few workers to represent the real workers of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Because those opposite do not understand this, let me cite the following case: I rang one of the social workers connected to the party yesterday and I asked, `What is the true story up there?'. She said she would give me a typical case that happened to her this morning. A seven months pregnant woman with a toddler at her heels had come in to her community centre for budgeting assistance for the week. Her husband brings home $280 net a week. They pay $110 a week rent. Because he has to move around for on site work he has to have a car, so take off $50 a week for petrol and another $50 a week for the car payments. This leaves $60 a week for housekeeping, food, clothes, medical expenses, electricity and so on. There is nothing left for the new baby and certainly nothing for services such as transport. This family has been put on the Housing Commission list, which is miles long. Meanwhile these people, who are battling and trying to do the right thing, trying to provide a future for their family, are living on welfare hand-outs.

With all the sincerity I can muster, I say that this is a shocking indictment of a Labor Party government that has been in office for five years and has neglected the working men and women of this nation. The financial pressures being placed on families are enormous, resulting in high divorce statistics and child poverty. This year one in every three marriages will end in divorce. In 1982-83, an average family paid 14 per cent of its income in tax. This now stands at an alarming 19 per cent-but that does not cover the tax on the milk, the ice cream, all those sorts of food items, and other items such as bathroom fittings, tools and so on. Studies have shown that the basic weekly cost of a child-keeping a child or caring for a child-ranges from $34 for a two-year-old to $92 for a teenager.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who can afford it?

—Very few people can afford it. This Government has made it a financial sacrifice for a parent to be home with children: the dependent spouse rebate is worth 32 per cent less than when this Government came to office. It is a disgrace that this Labor Party has so neglected its base. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is more at home in the board rooms of the multinational rich than he is with the working class men and women who put him into parliament. He has neglected those people. Let me quote from the report of a session of the Poverty Conference in Melbourne in April this year:

SPEECH.PARA: Policies were said to have created massive corporate success and produced a split in Australian society that has forced large sections of the working class into poverty, and in many ways added to the creation of crime.

The author of a paper on child poverty and crime built a picture of a culture of affluence for a minority in Australia. Contrasted with this was a very different reality for many people, demonstrated by increasing welfare dependence, personal bankruptcy, indebtedness, real wage reductions and unemployment. That is this Government's legacy of the last five years. However one looks at it-from the point of view of tax, housing, welfare or medical services-this Labor Government has failed the people of Australia and has failed its grass roots support, the working man and woman of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, would you kindly draw to the attention of the honourable senator that it is up to him and his Government to keep the numbers in this House? It is not up to the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The unemployment rate was 10.4 per cent early in 1983 when Mr Howard was the Treasurer of this country. So there was double digit unemployment as well as double digit inflation. When he left office the lowest income tax rate in this country was 30c in the dollar. That was the record; that was the fact. Look at the middle tax rate that was bequeathed to the Australian Labor Party by Mr Howard when he was Treasurer. Average workers had to pay 46c in the dollar. Forty-six cents was taken from every marginal dollar earned by taxpayers in this country when Mr Howard was the Treasurer. Let us look at the amount of tax free income that was available to taxpayers when Mr Howard was the Treasurer in this country. At that time the threshold for tax free income was $4,595. My estimate is that those cuts will be between $15 and $20 a week. There will be a very significant reduction in personal income tax paid by ordinary Australians. That will have a significant effect on disposable incomes because reductions in tax rates, in tax paid per dollar, have a much bigger impact on disposable incomes than on nominal wage rises. So those tax cuts will have a significant corresponding effect in terms of money wage rises.

Let us also look at the record of Mr Howard when he was Treasurer in the field of indirect taxes. I am talking about taxes other than taxes on wages and salaries and company profits. Let us look at the area of consumption tax. We all know-in this Parliament and outside-that the Liberals favour a consumption tax. They are all in favour of taxing ordinary commodities bought by average Australian families. That is the way in which the Liberals would reduce living standards if they ever had the chance to occupy the treasury bench in this Parliament. It is important to note that the two major tax exempt areas of commodities in the Australian community are food and clothing. They are essentially free of any indirect tax at the moment. The only way in which a future Liberal government-if there ever were such a thing-could get substantial extra revenue from taxing commodities would be by taxing the areas of food and clothing. These are the areas in which they could obtain the most revenue. We could then find the Liberals taxing such vital things as children's shoes, bread and everyday food items which are exempt at the moment but which are under the shadow of Mr Howard's taxes.

We all know about Mr Howard's record as Treasurer. He was the Treasurer of this country in 1981-82. He brought down the Budgets in those two years when the biggest ever rises in indirect tax occurred in this country. In 1981 he lifted every one of the sales tax rates by 2 1/2 percentage points. In 1982 in his last Budget he followed that with a further rise of 2 1/2 percentage points in every sales tax rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I made a very worthwhile statement.

—I ask you to resume your seat, Senator Boswell. You have the right to stand at the conclusion of Senator Maguire's speech-being the preceding speaker-to make any personal explanation. I reject this matter of public importance. It is hypocrisy for this coalition to even suggest matters like this. It destroyed living standards in 1982. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance brought on by the Opposition today states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's neglect of the average worker as evidenced by the continual decline in living standards over the last five years.

I suggest to Senator Boswell, who introduced this matter, that to give real meaning to this debate it should not simply be limited to the average worker but include the average Australian whether or not he or she is employed. Sadly, neither the Government nor the Opposition can lay claim to having put forward policies which would lead to an improvement in living standards of the average Australian.

If we are to define the role of government as one to reduce inequality in our society by providing income, education, health and social security services to those in need, then the Government has failed. For instance, we have seen proposals to introduce tertiary fees which will restrict rather than improve access to what was once free education. We have seen the Treasurer (Mr Keating) bring down a Budget with an unprecedented surplus of $5.5m, largely funded through pay as you earn tax revenue. The Government continues to fund a health system which adheres to the outdated concept of traditional high technology, high cost, curative medicine rather than to cheaper and far more desirable preventive models of health care.

Nor has the Government managed to ensure that the benefits of economic prosperity are shared and enjoyed by all. The Government has been prepared to allow ordinary Australians to contribute more tax through bracket creep while at the same time lowering company tax rates from 49c in the dollar to 39c in the dollar-a move to be followed by a similar reduction in personal income tax rates at the top end of the tax scale.

All of this has taken place over the past five years under a Labor government. The mind boggles at the prospect of the coalition taking office now that it has been pushed so far to the right by Labor's policies and by the New Right, which is charting new frontiers in dry policies. In light of this it is ironic, if not hypocritical, as Senator Maguire suggested, that the Opposition should raise this matter of public importance as its concern for the well-being of the average Australian is hardly credible. The Australian Democrats believe that it is high time the Government undertook meaningful tax reform which will benefit all Australians, including those most in need, rather than the large corporations which make strange bedfellows, I admit, and as Senator Boswell has said, with the Labor Party and its dogma.

To raise the living standards of the average Australian the Democrats say that the Government should raise the tax threshold to avoid poverty traps, should eliminate tax loopholes which allow effective corporate tax rates to be as low as 10 per cent and should stop increases in taxes on basic food items and other necessities of life. Senator Maguire qualified his claim that foodstuffs are exempt from tax. Senator Boswell chose to forget-to be charitable-the fact that he and his coalition colleagues colluded with the Government to introduce taxes on fruit juices and flavoured milk, which are food products. It will be interesting to see what they do when the new range of taxes on food products comes before this Parliament and Democrat amendments are moved.

The Senate needs to be reminded of some facts concerning tax policy which affect the Australian people. Australian companies enjoy the second lowest tax burden of all Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, yet this Government is still soft on company taxation. Only 10 per cent of Australia's population owns 60 per cent of the total wealth. Over the past 10 years the contribution to total revenue by companies-by the corporate sector-has fallen from 17.8 per cent to 12.7 per cent, whereas the pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayer has increased his or her contribution to 55.8 per cent.

Meanwhile, there is no doubt that the living standards of average workers have declined over the last five years. The average worker earns less in real terms but pays more in tax and more for food, housing, gas, electricity, transport and most other purchases. The average worker also has less access to government services, such as health care, education, social security supplements and child care. They will have even less access to these services if the policies which are being proposed by the Government continue to be pushed through.

As a result of partial wage indexation and delays in implementing the second tier, 4 per cent productivity increase, there is little doubt that the bulk of the Australian work force has suffered a decline in the real value of wages since 1983. The Amalgamated Metal Workers Union has calculated that people on an annual pre-tax income of $25,000 a year have suffered a 10.7 per cent fall in the value of their wages since March 1983. John Halfpenny has claimed that real wages have fallen by 22 per cent since 1983. By the middle of 1988, some 50 per cent, or just over 50 per cent, of the work force had still not received the second tier productivity increase proposed by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's decision in March last year. Of that 50 or 51 per cent of the work force, the largest proportion are women, as Mary Owen recently pointed out in an interesting analysis of the effect of the second tier system. She also pointed out that this is because women are clustered in the less powerful unions, the lower paid jobs and are often outside the union-protected section of the work force. I quote from an article by Edna Ryan in this month's Women's Electoral Lobby National Bulletin:

It is inconceivable that the Government (and, for that matter the ACTU leaders who supported it) were not aware of the consequences of negotiating direct with the employer. It seemed that low paid workers or weaker unions without much power, were not expected to get the 4 per cent at all.

Edna Ryan issued a warning in that article. I think that it is an important warning, considering that this matter of public importance has been put up by the Opposition whose policy and whose actions in the Parliament this morning have been directed very much to freeing up that system; to breaking down the present industrial relations system. Edna Ryan said:

This is a serious warning to oppose collective bargaining in place of the industrial arbitration system. Those people who speak of ``freeing up'' the labour market mean just that-collective bargaining. Only the strong unions in essential industries stand much chance of keeping wages up with the cost of living.

While it is true that wages have dropped under Labor, the Opposition seeks constantly to deregulate the labour market; to crush unions so that wages can drop even further. That is what Senator Boswell and his colleagues engaged in in this chamber today during the debate on the industrial relations legislation. They want to give employers the power to continue to reduce wages, which would be the inevitable result of collective bargaining while we have high unemployment-that is, if the Opposition in government were successful in dismantling the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Cutting the unemployment benefit is another of its policy goals. I quote from an article entitled `Social justice and the low paid worker' by Flora Gill of the Department of Economics at Sydney University:

Inequality of bargaining power is perhaps not an urgent issue when the labour market is very tight for a prolonged period. It becomes acute, however, when an economy plunges into a state of high national unemployment with no end in sight. With little alternative employment prospects, the low-paid worker on his own-
she should probably have used the term `her'-

in an over-crowded market cannot resort to a quit-threat in an effective manner. It is a well-established empirical fact that the quit rate of the work-force drops sharply as unemployment increases. The need for protection, therefore, especially for the low-paid worker, is even more urgent if we are resigning ourselves to having a significant level of national unemployment for the foreseeable future.

That represents a considerable warning in terms of the Opposition's policies. Previous speakers have said that the average worker pays more tax. In September 1985, in the tax cuts announced as part of the Government's tax reform package, the company tax rate was reduced. Subsequently, it was reduced to 39c. The highest marginal tax rate was reduced from 60c to 49c and the next individual tax rate went from 48c to 46c to 40c. As a result of those tax cuts, people on $15,000 a year who were paying 18.2 per cent of their income in tax were expected to have that rise to 19 per cent by 1987. Those on $24,000 at that time-that is, those on average weekly earnings-were paying 25.6 per cent as a percentage of income and that was to rise to 26.4 per cent. Those on 30,000 were paying 29.8 per cent and that was expected to drop slightly to 29.6 per cent. By contrast, those on $50,000 were paying 40.7 per cent and that was expected to drop to 37.4 per cent. In other words, the lowest paid and those on welfare benefits and paying some tax would pay more in order to finance the tax cuts for those who were better off. At the same time, Mr Keating was promising the most rigorous restraint on public sector outlays-not the Budget deficit, which has since come into surplus. That meant the social wage component of income would be falling at the same time.

It was announced in the May economic statement that the company tax rate would be reduced to 39c. It is now argued that this must be followed by a similar cut in the top personal tax rate; otherwise the highest taxpayers will incorporate and get the benefit of the lower company tax rate. If the top rate is reduced to 39c, the cost to revenue for that alone will be $1,000m. There will be no benefit for the 90 per cent of PAYE taxpayers with a taxable income of $35,000 a year or less. People with a taxable income of $50,000 a year will gain an additional $1,500 a year and those earning $100,000 will gain an extra $6,500 a year. Does anyone imagine that there will be a reduction of 10 percentage points, or anything like that amount, in the tax paid by wage and salary earners? Not at all. It is not possible because the total cost would be $12 billion. The major beneficiaries of cuts to social welfare expenditure, therefore, which have produced the Budget surpluses, will not be the average worker; they will be the corporate raiders and the paper shufflers, who are allowed to make huge profits and pay little or no company tax.

At the base of much of this is the Government's failure-a failure which is not criticised by the Opposition-to refuse the corporate giants the opportunity to negatively gear foreign borrowings for largely unproductive company takeovers. It is the major tax rort which this Government has left in place and which is reducing the living standards of all Australians. What is particularly galling is that Senator Boswell and his Opposition colleagues have shown no concern about redressing this problem. They support their wealthy mates. They are currently losing the contest that goes on in this place and in the political marketplace to attract the wealthiest Australians back to what has been in the past their traditional political base, the Liberal-National Party coalition, because most of the privileged have realised that a Labor government does even more to preserve and increase the wealth of the wealthiest Australians than would the Liberal and National parties.

As I have said, Senator Boswell and his colleagues have voted in this chamber to restore negative gearing for property investors. They then complain about average income earners not being able to purchase homes, to realise the Australian dream. Those people are currently in competition with the speculators, the investors, at the auctions when they try to buy their homes and fulfil that dream. That negative gearing rort is also available to high income earners who want to buy shares. The Australian Democrats were the only ones who opposed it when this Government introduced the measure. It is not being done at the expense of the Alan Bonds of the world.

Senator Boswell and his colleagues have also voted in this chamber to tax fruit juice and milk while the Democrats urged them to vote with us to protect the diminishing incomes of the average worker. While the Democrats agree with the substance of the matter of public importance raised by Senator Boswell, we emphasise the fact that the situation would be immeasurably worse under a New Right, Liberal-National Party government with a dog eat dog industrial relations system and a user pays community infrastructure system for health, education, communication and other services. I observe in conclusion that such a spectre also hovers over my home State of Victoria on the eve of a State election in which the Liberal leader, Jeff Kennett, and the National Party have run off a list of pork-barrel promises which top the $1 billion mark which they say will be paid for by savings-savings, presumably, on schools, hospitals, trains, roads and other services, wages and jobs, particularly jobs, as Mr Kennett has already said, in the transport industry. I am sure, however, that Victorians will reject this gung-ho confrontationist reduction in services approach which is the same approach as Senator Boswell and his colleagues would take, to the even greater disadvantage of average Australians and workers in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Canberra Times on Tuesday last, Mr Kelty, Mr Keating's mate, told us that we were living in a paradise. It seems we have gone from Mr Keating's banana republic to Mr Kelty's paradise. But is it really a paradise for the wage earner? The simple answer is no. It is a fool's paradise; it is an illusory paradise. There is no paradise for the average wage earner. I will list some of the changes that have occurred in this area in the past five years. Victorians' real average weekly earnings fell by 4 per cent in the period 1985-86 to 1987-88. What is actually left to spend-and that is what counts-has been reduced even further due to bracket creep. The single income family on average weekly earnings now pays $119 per week tax compared with $65 in March 1983. It is equivalent to an extra 5.3 per cent of its weekly income going to the Government.

Senator Maguire used a spurious argument when he used the base tax rate as an indicator of the level of tax being paid by wage earners. The simple fact is that inflation has pushed workers into higher and higher marginal tax brackets, so the average tax rate has gone up from 17.6 per cent in 1983 to 22.9 per cent this year. What does this mean? It means that the average family needs $44 more per week to restore its real disposable income to its March 1983 level; that is, after paying taxes, to have the same purchasing power as it had in 1983, the family needs $44 more per week.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said $56 a while ago.

—Senator Maguire needs to listen to the date. It is $44 now and by the end of this year it will be $56. In this new-found paradise the average weekly earner who has managed to get into the housing market is paying 27 per cent of his wage on his home loan compared with 19.2 per cent in 1983. Eight per cent more of his weekly income is going out and paying for housing loans. If a person is renting, the story is the same. There is an increase in the proportion of income being spent on rent. When the average weekly earner goes out to shop, the dollar does not go as far as many items are now out of reach. Twenty-five per cent fewer new cars were purchased in Victoria last year than two years before. It does not take much to imagine what reduced access to private transport means for rural people and those in outlying suburbs of Melbourne.
—There is an increase this year, though.

—Senator Maguire has already had his say. Anybody who runs a household budget knows how little is left after housing and transport costs have been paid for. By the way, I have not included the increase in the amount taken out for Medicare. The pay packet is even less than it was five years ago as a result of the increase in the Medicare levy. In Victoria, where people pay 20 per cent more in State taxes per head-this is supposed to be a paradise-than in other States, there is even less to spend. There are ever increasing electricity, gas and water charges, to say nothing about the soaring costs of staples such as food and clothing. This so-called paradise that Mr Kelty talks about has been achieved for workers in the unions with muscle. It has been a wilderness for people in the weaker unions and for those who are unemployed. I wonder whether members of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association, to whom Mr Kelty was speaking, think it is paradise. Has this largely female union, with its strong part time and casual labour force, seen wage increases to match those of the metal workers? Wage rises won by strong unions were not won on the basis of productivity through most of the 1970s and 1980s. Instead, they were won on the basis of industrial blackmail. And at what cost? The cost is clear. Let me quote from an editorial in the Australian Financial Review of Monday this week:

SPEECH.PARA: After almost two decades, and hundreds of thousands of words of rhetoric, an important Reserve Bank research paper has effectively put to rest the hoary old issue of the relationship between labour costs and employment.
The Reserve's paper comes on the top of recent assessments from the Federal Treasury and the Economic Planning Advisory Council which each back what many an intelligent person knew by intuition-
there are some not very intelligent people around who did not know this-
that one man's pay rise is another man's job.

Clearly then this paradise has been achieved by Mr Kelty, by Mr Halfpenny, who fortunately did not make it into this chamber, and by their union mates at the expense of those who do not have jobs. What has happened to their living standards? They are the ones who have been condemned to five years `hard Labor'. Look at what the union movement has done to our young people. Youth unemployment has been consistently over 20 per cent on a seasonally adjusted basis until February this year when productivity linked wage increases finally started to bite. That is what we mean by one person's wage rise being another person's job.

Time does not permit me to enlarge on how living standards of those relying on fixed or unregulated incomes, such as farmers, have declined. Only last night I was speaking on the telephone to two pensioners, two of my constituents, who told me that in the last couple of years they had had to employ a taxation agent to do their tax returns, because the tax laws have become so complicated; and they really cannot afford the money it costs to employ a tax agent.

This Government needs to ask the pensioners about their living standards. If it goes out and about and asks what is really happening it will be told by the pensioners. Tomorrow it will be told very clearly what the Victorians think about declining living standards. It is evident that over the past five years the purchasing power of the average weekly wage has been reduced and the living standard of the average worker has declined dramatically.

What is the prognosis for the future? I suggest that it will not be easy. The Hawke Government has so mismanaged the economy that its most senior economic adviser indicated this week that, given the Government's manipulation of economic policy instruments, there is only one degree of freedom. He claimed that the only move left to shift pressure off the balance of payments is through the blunt instrument of monetary policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Higher interest rates.
—The effect of this will not be selective. The impact will affect all Australians-home owners and renters alike. The honourable senator is right; it will mean higher interest rates.
—For the average family.
—The average family will be paying higher interest rates.
—See today's Melbourne Sun.

—I was just about to say that this morning's Melbourne Sun warns Victorians that they are heading for a rise of $22 in monthly loan repayments. But why is it not happening now? The Federal Government is stalling so that its mates in Victoria can have another chance at increasing taxes and charges in my State. It seems that, for many, Mr Kelty's paradise will be a paradise postponed until after Mr Hawke's mates have had a chance in Victoria. SPEECH.PARA: It seems from this matter of public importance that the Opposition may come along to the next national wage case and support John Halfpenny, whom it has blackguarded in such a dastardly fashion so far. Will members of the Opposition come along and say to members of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, `Living standards have fallen. It has gone from 0.3 per cent per annum, over the previous 10 years, to an expected growth this year of 12.8 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Relative to the other States though, Senator.

—All right, relative to the other States. I will give the honourable senator the figures. The increase in private business investment in Victoria from 1982-83 to 1986-87 was 8.1 per cent in Victoria and 4.7 per cent for the rest of Australia. According to projected Budget estimates this year, 1988-89, the expected increase in private investment in Victoria is 12.8 per cent compared with 4.7 per cent for the rest of Australia. SPEECH.PARA: The Government's neglect of the average worker as evidenced by the continual decline in living standards over the last five years.

As soon as we get up to talk about that and as soon as we start to win the debate, the Opposition says, `We want to change the debate. We want to go back to the 1970s now'. We guarantee that under a Liberal Government there will be no retrenchments and that your position will be secure. Reductions in the numbers in the Public Service will be by natural attrition, redeployment and early retirement schemes.

When we are talking about the living standards of people we are really talking about what sort of work they have and what sort of job they are going to pursue. The leader of the alternative government in Victoria, Mr Kennett, the day before the election, finds it necessary to reassure people about what he said previously about causing unemployment in the transport industry and, no doubt, others as well.
