Whereas the Cain Government has produced premiums of something like 2.4 per cent, the Victorian Liberals want to take us back to the days when premiums were over 37 per cent in the meat abattoirs, over 24 per cent in the brewery industry and over 28 per cent in the sawmills and planing mills. The honourable senator is very sincere in his approach. It is not just a matter of putting up something for discussion. He really means it. He cannot see that if he goes down the line he suggests disaster will befall us all.

That education was neglected under the old Fraser regime.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at child-care, an essential service. Child-care places have increased under this Government, and with great help from the Cain Government, from 46,000 to 110,000.

The next thing I want to talk about in the dying minutes of my speech is the family assistance supplement. Honourable senators opposite say that we have neglected the living standards of Australians. The family allowance supplement has helped over 140,000 families in Australia-each of those families having an average of 2.4 children. I ask honourable senators to reflect on that. We have given those families $22 a week for children up to 12 years of age and $28 a week for children aged 13, 14 or 15 years. In December 1988 that is to increase to $24 and $31 respectively. There will be changes to rent assistance. These were announced in the Budget to help low income families in the private market by recognising the extra cost of renting with children.

Home loan interest rates are likely to rise within the next few weeks . . .

SPEECH.PARA: These statements are official-speak for, yes, the Budget forecast is looking very sick . . .

Even sicker is the expenditure explosion under the Cain Labor Government. After seven Labor Budgets expenditure has increased at an annual rate of 3 per cent in real terms. Are they getting more out of this Government, or is it just that there are more employees under Mr Cain? Victorians have the highest rates of payroll tax, the highest rates of land tax, the highest rate of stamp duty on land transfers, and many other stamp duties and other State taxes. The massive financial mismanagement by the Cain Labor Government is almost unbelievable.
—Even Don Dunstan had to leave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to have the opportunity to participate in this debate on the so-called matter of public importance proposed by Senator Boswell. It is interesting that I have more time than was originally scheduled because so many of the Opposition speakers could not find enough argument to sustain even 15 minutes in support of this piece of nonsense. (Quorum formed) Unlike the Opposition, fortunately I will not have any trouble filling in the time. Senator Lewis did not need to help me out by calling a quorum to try to stop me speaking on this matter. But the fact of the matter is that anybody who has listened to any of the arguments from the Opposition will know that there are only three problems with the matter of public importance proposed by Senator Boswell. It is economically illiterate, it is insincere, and it is irrelevant.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, let me talk about sincerity. We suddenly find this new-found concern about average workers. We have seen crocodile tears from members of the Opposition on this subject. The only time that people on the Opposition benches ever see an average worker is when they call him into their office to sack him. They have never actually met one working on the job. Their only contact with workers is when they are trying to cut their wages. They do not have any concern about average workers. They think they have found some statistics that they do not understand and so they have tried to make a cheap political point.

I suppose the redeeming feature of the matter of pubic importance is that it is irrelevant. Senator Lewis was an example of its insincerity and irrelevance. The honourable senator enthusiastically tried to speak in defence of the average worker, but the only passion he worked up was in defence of people who invest in housing in Victoria. He told us how sad it was that they were constrained by legislation that protects tenants. Not too many average workers would share his concern, even if he got his facts correct. The matter of public importance is irrelevant for two reasons: firstly, we are fortunate in that we are not going to be afflicted with the policies of the Opposition; and, secondly, in none of the three speeches from the Opposition was there one positive point about what ought to be done.

In the few minutes I have left I want to make two points about economic illiteracy. Members of the Opposition do not understand the difference between the points that Senator Walsh has made so effectively in the last two Question Times about the increase in household disposable income per capita and the so-called statistics about living standards which they are trying to drag up. They fail to understand that two things that are not in their figures are reflected in the household disposable income figures in the Budget. Those figures show that in the last six years there have been four years of increases and two years of declines, the biggest decline being in the last year of the Fraser Government.

The differences are twofold. Firstly, there are a million more people in jobs now than there were when this Government came to office. Average workers are actually better off because they are in employment. The people that the Opposition would like to put out of work know that they are better off. They are in a job and they intend to stay in a job. The second element that is not reflected in the Opposition's statistics is the family allowance supplement, so effectively described by Senator Maguire and Senator Cooney.

In the time available to me the last point I want to make about the Opposition's economic illiteracy concerns the continuing carping on the fact that the Secretary to the Treasury has said that the only tool the Government has left is monetary policy. Fortunately, I know that Senator Boswell and others would not know the reality: if we do not use monetary policy, there are only two other choices-wages policy or fiscal policy; that is, we would have to cut either wages or government expenditure. It is impossible to conceive how we could improve the living standards of average workers if we cut either of those. No-one on the Opposition side was able to understand that point, so members of the Opposition did not have to address it. At least they did not have to face the intellectual challenge of asking, `How am I going to accommodate this difference?'.

In the brief time that remains I want to say that I know the people of Victoria will have the wisdom to see through the transparency, inadequacy and illiteracy of the argument that was put by Senator Boswell. I have appreciated the opportunity given to me as a result of the inadequacy of the Opposition speakers to speak for a few minutes. I have enjoyed that opportunity.
